Fallout New Vegas is a startlingly poingaint return to form for the fallout series, by obsidian entertainment.  After several missteps, through half-baked, slightly off sequels(brotherhood of steel, tactics, and fallout 3) the fallout brand was in serious danger of becoming another samey, annualized series.   Thankfully, Obsidian entertainment was able to step in, and right the nearly capsised intelectual property, with this entry in the series - new vegas!  Heralding the return of smart writing, and an intelligently built, internally consistent world, new vegas successfully washes the taste of several of the more, dissapointing, developments brought on by fallout 3 and tactics. It's easier to forget the fact that harold the ghoul is now a tree, and the brotherhood is stomping around, dumbly white-knighting around the east coast, when things in post apocalyptic california are still so barren, harsh, yet filled with the kind of interesting characters, and situations that make a proper fallout RPG.  The interactivity of the world makes for a great improvement in this spinoff-sequel, granting the player the ability to really make a difference with regard to outcomes and dispositions of the various factions, and individuals, in the sprawling new vegas wastes. This interactivity comes in the form of properly implemented skill checks, stat, and influence prompts, and even situations calling for the prescence of a specific perk! These opportunities to leverage the advantage of, not just a properly built character, but a uniquely built one, lead to interesting gameplay situations, and most importantly, a lot of choice and consequence, which at it's core, lends the player a feeling of truly influencing the virtual world. For me at least, this is very enjoyable, and lies at the heart of any true fallout experience, as much as the aesthetic ever does.  And, speaking of the aesthetic, I'm happy to report that the fallout aesthetic is alive and well in new vegas! After tactics and fallout 3 took a swing, a very close swing, and missed in terms of setting, it is refreshing to see new vegas do fallout so much justice!  The abandonment of the seriously misunderstood 'FIFTIES!' setting that pervaded fallout 3, is a breath of fresh air, and it's replaced by the more grim, yet interesting and entertaining atmosphere of the earlier games. The reflection of a society that collapsed at the peak of it's technological prowess, so obsessed with an idealized version of itself that it broaches no interference into that fantasy in it's media -- this, not a braindead FIFTIES! vibe, lies at the heart of the fallout setting, at least, the original fallout setting, and it is very, very nice to have it back.  Technically, the game is a disaster, a highly modable, customizable, disaster. Crashes will be present on any machine, with any mod configuration, with any settings. This is unfortunately unavoidable with this particular engine, and a holdover of the application's nature. Unfortunately the gambryo engine that beats at the heart of fallout new vegas is just as prone to crashes, and has been given just as little attention with regard to stability, as the engine in fallout 3 and skyrim. It hasn't changed, at it's core, since it has been used in morrowind, and it desperately calls for a true overhaul, not just the new coat of paint dashed on by skyrim's release. I hope a great deal, that the technical issues that plague new vegas, will be purged from the next iteration of the engine!  This technical mess is made up for, to a degree, by the vast modability of the engine, everything from visuals to basic gameplay elements can be modded and molded to the end - users preference, and this is an amazing achievement. This game truly is a sandbox version of the earlier fallout entries, which is something I adore!  In terms of gameplay, not much is truly altered from Fallout 3, nay, it is distilled and refined, into the RPG fallout 3 could have been. Skill points, stats, and perks can slot together in a wild array of different configurations, allowing the player to truly choose how they wish to navigate the wastes. Most character builds are viable, even the notoriously difficult social butterfly, using words and stealth to deal with the dangers of a post-nuclear las vegas!  I highly reccomend fallout new vegas to any fan of fallout, RPGs, or games in general. The price of admission is a level of patience with glitchy performance and coding, but the reward is an incredibly deep and satisfying RPG experience, wherein you, the player, determine the future of an entire civilization through your choices, and do so in many varied and creative ways, ways that are truly interactive, and truly follow your choices. A boast, that many games make, but very few live up to.

Fallout: New Vegas takes almost all the problems that Fallout 3 had and irons them out.   No longer is the story a line of events that you have no control over. Instead, it starts you off with a single goal: Find the guy who shot you in the head, and deal with him. When going to achieve this goal, your character becomes wrapped up in a nation-wide conflict in which your choices as a player will affect the outcome of an entire nation.  No longer are companions just blank slates with their only trait being they only associate with people who are good, bad and neutral. Companions will sometimes refuse to travel with you due to your karma being too low, but companions now have their own beliefs and goals. They will sometimes chime in on events that have happened, and all have very fleshed out back stories which not only tie them to the current events to the game, but also define their actions and how they react to you, as the player. You can betray them and destroy all they love, or you can help them accomplish their some of their most desired goals.  No longer are the main factions of the game just the morally evil and righteous. Instead of the being the almighty brotherhood of steel and the evil maniacs of the enclave, it's a pre-war style democratic government with all the corruption and scheming it had before the war. It's a a goverment who is run by a person inspired the ancient roman empire of old, with all of its good and bads. And there's also the in between. You can make the Mojave Desert independent through the eccentric mister house, a prewar millionaire who made plans hundreds of years in advance to take over the desert, or you can take over yourself by turning House's own creations against him.  They also have a long list of songs from the the 1950s that really fit the period and really just makes you have feelings only video games can create. In what other form of media can you wander around in a post apocalyptic desert with a floating Robot that plays action music and a Mexican Radiation Zombie gun slinger with western music about duels between an outlaw and a ranger playing in the background? Okay there might be like one other thing that does it, but I don't know of it.  The Gameplay hasn't been changed that much. It's the same first person open world sandbox. However slight improvments and additions have been made to the combat to add variety. Such examples are the addition of throwable weapons such as spears. You can also craft restoratives from the herbs you find in the desert, but this is more useful to those looking to roleplay.  The Graphics can look a little outdated. The engine is very old, but if you know anything about modding, you can easily make this game look up to date. Even without mods, the graphics aren't that bad. They server their purpose, nothing more and nothing less.  If you enjoyed Fallout 3, but felt is was lacking a little something (be that story, character or over all charm) I would HIGHLY recommend this game. If you are a fan of the classic Fallout 1 and 2, but didn't like the way bethesda took the Fallout 3 plot, I would highly recommend this. If you enjoy a good sandbox RPG with simple combat and lots of roleplaying opportunities, I recommend this game.  This game is charming as hell, can be serious and funny whenever it needs to be, and with recent rumors swirling around about Fallout: New Orleans being copyrighted, and that Obsidian being working on that, it is no better time to pick up this unappreciated gem of the last generation.   And, don't get me started on mods. I made this game play almost exactly like Fallout 4 with a few simple downloads.  TL;DR: Graphics: 6/10 Story: 9/10 Gameplay: 8/10 Music: 9/10  Overall: 8/10 For 20$, it's a steal, granting me nearly 100 hours of content even before mods.

Fallout 3 rocked my world when I first got my hands on it. How well does New Vegas do in comparison? It's difficult to answer.  Much is the same, but at the same time different. The game runs on the same engine and much of the content is very familiar. They did add plenty of new stuff though. There's a new, good soundtrack, if not a bit limited. Combat seems easier and less dependant on V.A.T.S. You can have several companions to help you out, but they're actually a bit too good.  The world's a bit less varied, smaller and not quite so open, but still packed with atmospheric places to discover. The gameplay's somewhat more linear and clearer in the beginning. Eventually, however, things becomes a spaghetti of quests that are both too easy and too hard, and different factions that conflict eachother. It's quite frustrating and worsened by bugs and inconsistencies.  It's a worthy sequel to F3, if a bit less than I had hoped for, and in many ways different. I still enjoyed it a lot and have no problem recommending it.

The Mojave Desert gives me Fallout 1/2 vibes. Obsidian did a great job pulling the reins of this game, and while not a lot of core gameplay has changed from Fallout 3 (sans damage threshold and similar mechanics), its still a game absolutely worth playing through and I would argue its better than Fallout 3. Though, as expected of any Betheseda game, its buggy and sometimes a little goofy in areas. If you loved Fallout 3, you will more than likely love this, and if this is your first Fallout game, you'll enjoy trekking through the desert with your robot/drunkard/sniper companion and laying waste to everything that so much as breathes at you funny. Many hours of enjoyment ahead.  As a side note, this game has an incredible modding community that can expotentially increase the hours you spend playing this game. Mods like Project Nevada change up the gameplay and balance immensely, and are highly recommended after your initial vanilla playthrough (or even for your first time because screw 'developer intent') and subsequent playthroughs. Ontop of that, there are mods that enhance your visuals, providing more darker nights or better indoor lighting, or changing the weather patterns and giving higher resolution textures for almost everything in the game from roads to guns, or ENBs that give a new pallete of color to the wasteland. Even fully voiced (New Vegas Bounties) mod quests.   This is a game absolutely worth your time and money, full price or on sale. Its a game that, while not incredibly polished and may have some questionable decisions, is not one to be missed. And hey, any questionable stuff can be fixed with mods, right? Right. My 46 installed mods stand with me on that.

Fallout: New Vegas  A post-apocalyptic Role Playing Game set in the Mojave desert, a tale of revenge, origin and answers. Also a tale of slicing people up with chainsaws, or a lone neanderthalian miner who's only friend is his trusty sledgehammer, or a tale of a technophobic businessman, or a tale of whatever you want, really.  I've played this game for 300 hours, and I have completed all the achievements, that should mean I liked my experience with Fallout: New Vegas - at least for the most part. I will go through mostly the negative things about the game, (there are a lot of positives too, but I'm better at focusing at negative stuff) since that's easiest for me. A more positive person would probably give the game a +25% rating or so. Don't get me wrong, this is a GOOD game. Here is my ranking of the different elements in the game, and why:  Fallout: New Vegas 6,29 /10 Customization: 6/10 Visuals: 5/10 Combat: 6,33/10 Storytelling: 7/10 Gameplay: 7/10 Dialogue: 6,5/10 DLC Content: 5,5/10 Music: 7/10  CUSTOMIZATION: (6/10) *Character creation: (6/10) Good amount of sliders and options, though for some reason they always have to make your face tiny and put strange scanline filters all over it so you can't see it clearly. Not too many hair style choices, and no tattoos or similar for some reason. It is decent though. *Crafting: (6/10) During your travels you can craft quite a few items, and although there are fewer weapons to craft than in Fallout 3 you can craft a LOT of consumables, some of wich are really good, and some of wich are basically useless. *Weapon modding: (6/10) An alright modding system, though I would've liked to see more options, especially side-graded mods instead of straight upgrades.  VISUALS: (5/10) An alright looking game, definently suffers from a monotone colour palette. *Animation: (6/10) There are definently some animation glitches, and the general quality is quite basic. *Rigging: (5/10) Most of the rigging seems to be pretty well handled, except for when an NPC is following a given route, then it seems to be twitching along. *Colour Palette: (3/10) Monotone colour palette. The palette is desaturated, (wich is good for that post-apocalyptic feel) but then someone had the bright idea of putting sepia filters all over everything in 70% of the game. If the filters were toned down to maybe 10-20% strength it would contribute. When done in small amounts these filters can really set the mood for certain places, but when it's there all the time it just becomes bland. *Graphical quality: (6/10) In several places you can see mirrored textures and the like, but most enemies are well handled, designed and executed.  COMBAT: (6,33/10) Combat is rewarding, bashing someone's face in, taking a long-ranged headshot or obliterating them with plasma is good fun. *Gun combat: (7/10) Both energy weapons and ballistic. Single-shot weapons gameplay is good in this game, especially Sniper rifles and Shotguns feels great. However,  due to the small auto-aim feature included in the game, fully automatic weapons act weird and not the way you'd expect them to act. The same is true for a few pistols as well, but most of the weapons act the way you want them to. Not a big difference from Fallout 3. * Melee combat: (6/10) Both unarmed, throwing and melee weapons. As New Vegas introduced a few unarmed combat techniques, unarmed combat got a bit more interesting.  However, these techniques replaces your moving power attacks - wich to me is poorly handled. There is a decent variety of unarmed weapons available. The throwing weapons introduced feels like a joke, they disappear when they hit something, and seems like the team just finished it as fast as they could. Melee weapons works out pretty well, though there aren't many interesting melee weapons (at least early in the game). * Explosives: (6/10) Thrown explosives, Big explosive guns. There is a lot of explosives in this game. Especially dynamite, wich is decent but slow. Bigger explosive weapons feels very situational, and has only a few uses that don't make you think there was a better way of dealing with the problem.  STORYTELLING: (7/10) Good storytelling, the game motivates you to explore and make choices. *Main quest: (6/10) Compelling and exciting at first, but getting lost along the more enjoyable side quests. You basically lose interest about it as you move on,  and when you are done it doesn't really feel that rewarding. Lots of choices though, wich makes it all better. *Side quests: (7/10) There are a lot of interesting side quests in the game, motivating you to explore the wastelands.  *Characters: (8/10) Your companions have their own backgrounds and will enjoy or dislike choices you make while wandering the wastes, you will get to know characters in the game more the more time you spend with them, and the more places you visit with them.  *Background: (7/10) The Fallout universe is rich in backstory and New Vegas isn't afraid to use that backstory to tell it's tale.  GAMEPLAY: (7/10) No huge flaws, but a few small quirks you should be aware of. *Game modes: (7/10) Normal mode and Hardcore mode. Hardcore mode means you actually need sleep, food and water or suffer attribute penalties, followed by death.  However, as you are in a desert, you will need to drink regularly. *Logistics: (7/10) Walking around is pretty basic in a game, but somehow the developers managed to make walking and running quite unresponsive and sluggish. Your character doesn't stop when you no longer press the 'forward' key, it takes a fraction of a second before they acctually stop. There are invisible walls spread throughout the world, mostly to deny access to shortcuts over mountains, but sometimes in very strange places. Fast travel works just as in Fallout 3, Oblivion and Skyrim, nothing strange going on.  DIALOGUE: (6,5/10) Very good dialogue options, although just because you CAN say something doesn't mean you should. Just like in real life. *Speech and 'checks' (8/10) Talking, Attribute/skill 'checks' inside of a dialogue is either a failed or passed, and you can see wether you reach the requirements or not. No more '65%' to make it or not, in this game you either have '6/10 STR' or you don't. This is a great system, much better than in Fallout 3.  A huge plus for making talking your way out of almost every problem a possibility. *Non-Important Character lines (5/10) are extremely repetetive, and they re-used lines of dialogue even across different voice actors, wich is both a huge waste of potential and immersion.  DLC CONTENT: (5,5/10) Overall my experience with the DLCs in New Vegas has been positive, and I've played them all several times. *Honest Hearts (5/10) A story that isn't that compelling and you only get along with because you want to see the new place. Some new weapons but nothing special. Interesting new locations though. You forget about this one pretty quickly. *Old World Blues (7/10) The comical, science-based one. Repetetive at times, but so charming you forgive it quickly. Interesting new locations and items.  Adds a little more customization to the game, wich is always welcome. *Lonesome Road (8/10) In my opinion, the best post-apocalyptic feeling in the game. A good amount of new items, a storyline that keeps reminding you about it.  Interesting new locations, just the right size for a DLC. Lots and lots of background information if you are curious enough. *Dead Money (2/10) A frustrating DLC, boring, maze-like environments and a few, not-too-exciting new items, not very interesting characters, way too long. I do not recommend unless you really  want 100% achievements completed.  MUSIC: (7/10) Most of the music is enjoyable and well adapted for the 'wild west' feel of the game. It gets repetetive after a while, but it's pretty good nonetheless.

Every 2-3 months, for some inexplicable reason, I get the sudden itch to mod New Vegas to an unbelievable point. I install the game, download around 100 mods, sometimes even up to 200. Then I try to get all of them to behave. I then begin to play until I am able to make sure every mod has done what it is supposed to. After that, I uninstall everything.  Then the cycle begins anew.  Don't know why, maybe I like to subject myself to a weird sort of stress. It's like a challenge that no matter how much you are failing, the worst that could happen is that you stop your game from starting.  So basically, New Vegas is one of the few games out there that have the dankest of mods, and modding itself is such a great feeling for some reason.  So not only do you get a neat game, but if you enjoy modding just for modding, this is for you.    It's a great platform to start modding and a great one to get some practice in. If you like to mod, this game is a must have. If you like to create stuff for games, this also is a must have.

The occupants are humorless and oppressive. But I bow and curtsey. I smile and nod. I sweep their floors. I fetch their lost equipment. I facilitate their coups. They're easy to please. Such complete isolation... how could it not breed ignorance? Preservers of culture. Defenders of history. Cowards in basements. So excited they are that I travel openly. Drop the slightest hint that I'll assist their cause, and in two weeks I'm a member. They will not be missed.   When I enter their archive, they salute me. My visible disgust is taken as respectful intensity. It's a tight community. Everyone already knows how hard I've been fighting for them. Among the access panels in the archive sits a conspicuous red console. Right across the front of it in large letters: 'SELF DESTRUCT TERMINAL'. What? And the password is.... 'SECLUSIONIST'? A culmination of all the technology in the history of the human race and they didn't f*cking child proof the suicide machine.   Veronica. Would you mind heading back to the Lucky 38? Around the corner and through a pair of confused scribes. Up from the archive and past a wide eyed paladin. Only one person isn't in shock. Only one person is sprinting towards the exit. Paladin hands start going for weapons. My lab coat flutters like a cape. Turrets begin to wind up. Ramos is blocking the exit, wide eyed as the others. He begins to speak. I arm a frag mine across his face, and drop it at his feet before his body hits the floor.  The lab coat flies like the wind. The mine detonates, and three pursuing Brothers are robbed of their final 10 seconds. The earth purrs as I reach the surface. A deep, low, satisfied rumble that turns the ground to jelly and sinks my boots an inch into the sand.  I watch the entrance for a day, but a trickle of smoke is all that emerges.  One of my people is satisfied. But how to manage the other?  Veronica is... irritated. Do you know what happened? Were you there? Did you.... did you do it?  _ Barter [23/90]: Know anyone that's looking to buy some power armor? I got, like, twenty. _ Speech [65/90]: HELIOS One shoots lasers down from space! Maybe they were test firing and... > [Lady Killer]: B*tch, please.   Veronica stays outside. Caesar grants only individual audiences. Typically this is an irritation, but given the topic of discussion, today it's a blessing. Yes, Caesar. The Brotherhood is no longer a threat. Your southern flank is clear.

Rating: 8.9/10.0 (Very highly recommended)  Obsidian Entertainment contains many of the original developers of the Fallout series, before the IP was sold to Bethesda in 2006.  In very much the same way that you would not allow anyone but J. R. R. Tolkien to write a sequel for the Lord of the Rings series, you should never let Bethesda write a sequel to the Fallout series.  What Fallout: New Vegas is; is the realization of Obsidian's dream to create Fallout 3: Van Buren. They might not have got the opportunity to make it as a 3D-isometric-turn-based game; but they did bring the world of Fallout to many fans who were 'seeped' in the novice pool by Bethesda's butchered pink-slime blender version.  For those of you who might be reading this in confusion and perhaps cringing:  In Fallout 1, you are the Vault Dweller, coming from Vault 13 - a vault designed to never be opened as a social experiment. The only reason the Overseer sent you out, is because the Vault's water purification system controller chip fried, and is impossible to replace. You fight Super Mutants, and discover the Brotherhood of Steel.  In Fallout 2, you are the descendent of the Vault Dweller, the Chosen One, sent out to find the G.E.C.K to help a tribal village from dying out due to drought, famine, and disease. You fight the Enclave.  In Fallout 3, Bethesda Edition, you are the Vault Dweller, coming from Vault 101, a vault designed never to be opened as a social experiment. You voluntarily leave to find your father, who is looking for a G.E.C.K, in order to activate a water purification system. You fight Super Mutants, the Enclave, and discover the Brotherhood of Steel.  Luckily, anyone who has played the Bethesda Edition is too young to remember the plots of Fallout 1 and 2, and probably has never played them; so upon discovering these concepts, thought that they were amazing and unique.  Needless to say, the difference between an Obsidian game, and a Bethesda game is as clear as day, as the difference between New Vegas and Fallout 3.  I highly recommend that you give New Vegas a playthrough, if not just for the story of NCR alone. It is direct canon to Fallout 2, makes many references to things that have occured in Fallout 1 and 2, and even has items and easter eggs directly from Fallout 2, if you know where to look. Big MT's story arc (DLC) is the canon ending from Van Buren, with Hoover Dam and Boulder City (formerly Boulder Dome) being the lead-up to it. The satelite weapon from Big MT however became HELIOS ONE.  E.g: Daisy Whitman in Novac comments on her experience as a Vertibird pilot that experienced a rotor malfunction over Klamath. ;)

What's this? A sequel to a groundbreaking new Fallout game with better, more polished gameplay (including better companions, one of which is a cyberdog instead of Dogmeat, a better faction system including an NCR faction, an increased focus on weapon mods, and much less dependence on randomized elements); a less sad, lonely, desperate tone; where the main character who wasn't from a Vault but gets a suit anyway's first gun is a somewhat-crappy rifle; which takes place in a different area to its immediate predecessor; with less focus on the story, unimproved graphics, a different antagonizing force, a final battle with a lot of allies against what is essentially a superhuman, Marcus the Super Mutant, a gambling town with 4 main forces running it, less immersion, a technically different dev from last time (with Chris Avellone), but with the publisher remaining the same, a cave with geckos and lots of toxic waste that you're not obligated to go to, and the Winchester P94 not being as legendarily good as it was in Fallout 1?  Alright, yes, the joke is that it's playing Fallout 2 to Fallout 3's Fallout 1. But unlike Fallout 2, the devs didn't either overreach themselves or just get incredibly lazy (I still can't tell which), and thus deliver an inferior product. Fallout: New Vegas arguably is a better product than Fallout 3, but, as I've said, it's less immersive and the atmosphere is less consistent. No, the Wild West's feel is the order of the day here (as is an increasingly elaborate and entertaining gun system), and though it's a lot of fun, it's probably a less engaging product than its predecessor. Still, get it right away. I'd probably put it put it just above Fallout 3, but, as ever, below Fallout 1.  By the way, I played the first 2 of the 4 DLCs at the time of writing, and they both offer up good weapons that you can keep at the end, as well as some fun stories and a lot of stimpaks and bobby pins, but not a lot else.  TL;DR It's a lot like Fallout 2 except less lazy, and it's Fallout 3's bigger, stronger, yet less somber big brother. Get it.  P.S. I've recently reinstalled F:NV for two reasons. One, it was a fun game and I wanted to replay it. Two, because I hadn't ever fully played out all of the DLC's (which I plan to remedy on this playthrough).  For those of you who don't know, Fallout: New Vegas is a first-to-third (over the shoulder ala Tomb Raider POV) post-apocalyptic RPG/Shooter. The setting is the southwest United States after a massive amount of bombs and time has elapsed. The world is in ruin and you've taken up work as a courier (think the Pony Express), except the story begins after you have been waylayed for your package. Upon waking up, you find yourself in the care of a kindly old doctor. He nurses you back to health and you begin anew in the wasted west.  Gameplay is pretty straight forward. The game plays a little easier to me to play in third person, although there are times that I switch over to FP to make a shot on someone. Your character is composed of Attribute stats as well as Skills and Perks. Attributes are core stats that affect percantages on things like To Hit, Critical Strike, or Carry Capacity. Skills add a direct bonus to the various types of things you can do in the game. Perks give your character a specialized flavor in the game as you level. Such things as better aiming ability, the ability to fix things better, or speeds you up in between actions. And speaking of actions, play is live, but action points recharge which ultimately power combat moves. This stays true to the entire series.  The game is full of interesting characters. Depending on how good your Speech is, you do or don't get a nice variety of different conversations out of the NPCs. There are even some NPCs that you can recruit to your cause. This is sometimes a good thing, sometimes not, in the game. One of my personal favorite followers is the droid that you can repair in a town not far from your starting point in the game.  One of the most useful aspects of the game is the VATS system. By hitting V on your keyboard, you bring up a hit location targetting system when in combat. It gives the percentage chance to hit different body parts on your enemies. This is great, since the game has different types of ammo for different situations (hollow points for unarmored targets or armor piercing for armored). In addition, shooting someone in their shooting arm may cause them to drop their weapon. Shooting someone in their leg may cause them to start limping. You can also just point and aim in live mode, but since the gun factors in your skill, the distance, and other random modifiers, you can miss even if you 'see' it as dead on in your sights.  There are other elements to the game that are enjoyable as well, including the crafting system. While rudimentary, it offers the ability to create simple concotions, drinks, food, and even armor and weapons. Travel is by foot, but once you discover a location, you can use your personal computer (called your 'Pipboy') to fast travel. Leveling up is fun, since you get skill points to spend and periodic points for new Perks.  I spent countless hours on the first playthrough, so I'm looking forward to reliving those times on this playthrough, plus seeing what all the DLC is about. I highly encourage buying the GOTY edition on this title to get all of the many extras that are in the game. It's fun, flat out and simple. Great game.

Okay, first, Look at the many hours I have logged into this friggin' game. If that don't tell you how good this game is, then... well... maybe this review will!  So after you get shot in the head, you are dusted off by Doc Mitchell and shoved out into the Mojave Wasteland. A quaint little place home to soldiers, romans, cowboys, escaped convicts, fancy cannibals, and giant poisonous bugs. Everyone's going nuts over Hoover Dam (yes, the same hoover dam) because whoever controls THAT, controls all the power and water in the mojave. You can choose who gets the dam, OR! OR! OR you can take it for yourself. Yes, you heard me, you can become the undisputed lord/lady of Post Apocolyptic Las Vegas.  Going off the beaten path, which you can do any time, things get interesting. You get your brain scooped out by pre-war scientists (one of whom is voiced by Doctor Venture.) You get sent to a big scary casino with a bomb strapped around your neck that goes off near decaying radios (which that place has plenty of) to swipe all the gold bars out of pure spite (or just walk out with a laser sniper rifle/shotgun hybrid) You go to a beautiful national park and meet tribals lead by a mormon mummy to save two tribes from the genocidal whitelegs and get a war club. You go through the sand storms and ruins of the Divide to save the world from being nuked again. It's one hell of an adventure.   It's got companions! A nine foot tall blue supermutant who thinks she's your grandmother. A robot doggie with brain damage. A drunk cowgirl. Veronica. An NCR sniper. A snarky scientist. And speaking of mods? Forget about it. It keeps on going! Super mutant race mods, weapon mods, quest mods, performance enhancers, it just goes on and on! If you can wrap your head around the GECK, you can probably mod the thing yourself. If you have this game and fallout 3, look up a mod called 'Tale of Two Wastelands.'  Are you still here!? The biggest 'plus' the game has are its DLC, my personal favourite is Dead Money because it combines horror and survival with a slight Silent Hillesque theme, with the 'cloud' replacing the fog from Silent hill. Already have it on Xbox 360 and had a great time there, even without DLC or mods for the game. BEST FALLOUT GAME IN THE SERIES. Great sense of humor mixed in. Bloody and satisfying kills. Sights on guns make this game far better than Fallout 3. The added sights probably make this game better than FO3 by itself. Also, Fallout 3 had a gloomy atmosphere but in Fallout New Vegas, the world seems more alive, with fantastic factions, each with it's own uniquness. I find myself only gambling sometimes in New Vegas, and that alone is so much fun. I chose to purge and rob various casinos, although I spared some so I could still gamble. I accidentally killed all of the preformers, so I could not watch any shows in Vegas. Oh well. I love the different companions, each matching each style you prefer. I'm not a melee type of guy, but Veronica is the best companion in my opinion, giving massive hits from her power fist to your enemies. Don't settle with the first one you aqquire though, switch them out (you can have two at a time) and decide which ones you like the best. You don't have to be a sole bad guy or good guy, you can be both, changing your relationships with each faction. The game can be difficult at times, but after defeating hard enemies like deathclaws, it's very satisfying. Even then, you can always find the perfect weapon to defeat each enemy. Regarding the setting of the game, the Mojave Desert is the BEST location for this game. Every post-apocalyptic game (or even movie) could be in a desert. Especially the Mojave. There's nothing better than wandering through the Mojave in Fallout New Vegas with the in-game radio playing. Speaking of the radio, the song list is great. The Fallout series as a whole is very retro-futuristic, taking place in the late future with sci-fi weapons, while STILL having classic 1950s music. It's so great to blow an NPC's head off while Frank Sinatra sings in the background. If you get sick of hearing the same song a lot, have no fear because there are mods that allow you to make an organized playlist. Glitches are also enjoyable, having a nice laugh whenever a scorpion glides through rocks like a ghost. A deathclaw even froze one time, so I had fun teasing it by jumping around. Pretending to be a classic cowboy can be fun too, with your character only having revolvers, hat and maybe a lever-action rifle. I haven't played Fallout 4 so I can't compare and contrast the two games. That being said, if you are willing to only buy ONE rpg game or fallout game, make it this one. PS: I didn't mention gameplay with mods or DLC because this review is solely for the regular game.

Ingredients 1/2 cup all-purpose flour 1 teaspoon granulated garlic Kosher salt and ground black pepper 2 boneless skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces 1 cup prepared breadcrumbs 1 large egg 1 cup vegetable oil Directions Place the flour in a resealable plastic bag and season with the garlic, 1 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Place the chicken pieces in the bag with the flour and toss to coat (work in batches). Transfer the breadcrumbs to a rimmed plate, season with salt and pepper and set aside. Whisk the egg and 1 tablespoon water in a medium bowl. Remove a piece of chicken from the flour, dip in the egg mixture, then the breadcrumbs, gently pressing the crumbs into the chicken, and set on a clean plate. Repeat with the remaining pieces of chicken. Heat the vegetable oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat. Add the chicken pieces to the pan (work in batches if needed) and brown on each side, about 8 minutes total. Use a spatula to transfer the chicken nuggets to a paper-towel-lined plate. Salt while hot and serve.

If you were to ask me what is my favorite game of all time it would be Fallout: New Vegas. It is one of the most immersive role playing games I have ever played. I used to live in Las Vegas when I was younger and walking in the mojave and the Strip in New Vegas felt very nostalgic to me with the long road trips and Neon lights. Now about the game. I consider this more true to the Fallout series than 3. Let's be honest here. Fallout 3 is good and I love it but the writing is fan fiction tier. Now Fallout: New Vegas stays true to the original games because of its setting and characters and the writing was just amazing and not a good vs evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like 3 did. Fallout: New Vegas has A LOT more weapons and rpg elements than 3 did and you don't feel like a invincible god like you did in 3. It's way more balanced and puts a sense of realism into it especially if you are playing on hardcore mode. The hardcore mode is a great addition for hardcore roleplayers and people who want a realistic approach and a challenge. The companions in my opinion were way better than fallout 3 and more memorable. My favorite companion is Rose of Sharon Cassidy for obvious reasons ;). I also loved the iron sights in this game and the option to mod your weapon to make it more powerful and accurate. Obsidian did a very good job for the animation and iron sights and makes you feel immersed when using it. The replayability in this game is insane! There are 4 different endings in this game but you can still play differently each playthrough and it never feels the same. The soundtrack in this game has got to be one of my favorite soundtracks ever, I'm talking about the radio. The mojave radio which consists of western/country music is so relaxing to listen to when you are out in the wasteland. If old western country ain't your thing then you can listen to Radio New Vegas which has swing music and legends like Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin. In conclusion, get this game. You will not regret a single penny. This game is art. It is the Mona Lisa and It deserves the praise it gets. I just want to thank Obsidian for making one of the greatest experiences I've ever had in gaming, you guys deserved to make Fallout 4 and have no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t due dates.

I have put way to many hours into this game. It is very very very good. You don't have to play Fallout 3 to play this. I've put about 80 hours into it including the DLC, which is totally worth it.

While this was enjoyable, and the DLC felt better written than the Fallout 3 DLC, overall it was smaller in many ways, and a disappointment having played it directly after FO3. 3 was a larger world, and had more to do in that world, when you found a location, chances were it had one to two levels above ground and possibly quite a large dungeon or sewer system, and was loaded with loot. NV had emptyville, population nobody, and nothing, often not even a tin can...town after town of cowboy movie sets, with no actors, windows and doors all boarded up. I ran into a random gang of mad max type goons once, about seven or eight came at me out of nowhere and I thought ok, this is going to be good, bigger groups to fight. that was unfortunately quite rare.   The changes to the economy from 3 were also quite jarring, suddenly everything costs an absolute fortune, repairing some pretty average combat armour cost me 11,000 caps...come on now, in 3 you could buy several sets of power armour for that and still have change for a fatman. I brought a tri beam laser rifle off a travelling merchant, with a mod, all up best part of 8,000. it was a really underpowered weapon compared to the plasma defender or grenade launcher or even a 10mm machine gun.  Food used to be a good sale item, no longer, meds, used to be worth picking up, no longer, even enemy armour and weapons are way more trouble to cart around than they are worth. Best thing I can say is do the Big Empty DLC as soon as you can because you will get a cool base with a really valuable shop you can fast travel to immediately, and you can turn all the burned books and empty bottles into more valuable treasure there as well. It makes carting junk around much less of a hassle if you can just beam there and dump it off right away.  I think I ended up exploring more of the wasteland than I was meant to because I couldnt find a way inside Vegas itself for a long time, but that paid off once you start getting a few of the 'world tour' type of fetch quests going to a list of places you have already unlocked is a lot less painful than having to slog all over the map on foot from the closest fast travel point. Once you get inside Vegas itself, the actual story picks up and the fun comes back into the story a little so if thats the last part you do, it will end on a high point, but if you get there too early you will sort of get a bumrush to the end of the story and miss a lot of the side quests, some of which were not half bad.  I would also suggest thinking about what your goals are as you can end up doing a mission and closing off A LOT of other potential storylines. I thought I'd see what happened if I did X, and next thing you know I've failed about six quests in a row, some of which I hadnt even started, and my reputation got all broken too, suddenly the gang I had completely massacred liked me more than the NCR who one mission before had idolised me, now they were just ok.....so plan where you want to end up is all I'm saying.  Is this a good game....yeah, I guess. Is it as good as Fallout 3 like everyone says...I really dont know how that became the favoured answer, theres less to do, and way less at stake. Oh and the music which was so awesome in 3, well you get bugger all, I had heard johnny guitar and Big Iron about a thousand times each and thats no exaggeration. Mr New Vegas is a poor substitute for threedog.  Buy it cheap, play it once and thats enough really.

If you loved Fallout 3 you'll love this, because it's more of the same goodness with some improvements. You'll spend hours wailing on giant insects, mutated creatures, oh and people that want to kill you for star bottle caps. I swear the bartender in goodsprings tried to steal my star bottle caps, so I punched her head off and then everyone in the bar started trying to steal them.. needless to say, they didn't get them.. heheh...  There's plenty of skills to level up, which of course are required to pick higher level doors or wield weapons efficiently. You can also raise these skills with skill books scattered around the wasteland which increment the skill by 3 or 4. The ones that raise them by 10 are a lie; they're temporary to give you an edge. Plus you get perks every few levels that make you even more awesome.  One of the improvements was with the karma system. Aside from the basic Good, Bad, and Neutral, you now have split karmas with different factions such as the NCR and power puff gangers. You can either make these groups idolize you as their god, or hate and fear you like you're the devil.   One of the other notable improvements was being able to add modifications to your weapons, such as a silencer or a scope. This is one of my personal favorites, because you can customize the weapon however you want when you find a mod. My only gripe was the lack of a naming feature for the weapons, because I wanted to name my power fist 'Rock 'em Sock 'em'.  Now if you'll excuse me.. I'm going to go back to punching things into bloody messes and hauling items back to my hoard.

Fallout: New Vegas  Pros:  - Massive amount of content. As far as content:price ratio, this is an amazing value for your money.  - The side quests and storylines of some of the Vaults are a lot of fun to investigate and discover. I actually enjoyed the side quests a lot more than the main plot simply because the main plot wasn't all that creative.  - The enviornment with regards to the areas around Vegas (Hoover Dam, Nellis, etc.) is spot on and fun to explore.  - The Sound track is phenomenal. This is one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in a game. It fits the theme and enviornment so well.  Cons:  - I was disappointed that the 'main character' (aka you) has no real personality. You make choices through the game, but there is no sense of character. I suppose YOU are the character and your personality is the one playing the game, but I would have much more preferred an actual written character to make choices for. How is there supposed to be a story without a fully developed main character? This is one of the games major pitfalls.  - I didn't personally find the main plot line all that interesting. Whenever I ran out of side quests I would be sad to have to go back to the main plot... The side quests were way more fun.   - Exploring and getting to certain areas can become EXTREMELY tedious. There are so many impassible terrains that you are generally forced to take very long routes in order to get to some places that seem like they are easy to get to. It's very deceiving.   - The main plot has a ton of choices for you to make. Unfortunately, I felt like there were so many choices that I became overwhelmed and had no clue what to do. I personally like to finish all quests that I am given. You can't do this approach in New Vegas though because once you choose sides of a certain faction, you risk failing all the missions for their opposition. This is frustrating to someone who wants to see all the content. You would have to make multiple playthroughs or very specific save points in order to see all the content. I would have much preferred no faction oppositions and just the ability to do all the quests.  Overall, the game content is quite solid and has one of the best sound tracks I've ever heard (seriously, I keep singing those songs in my head even when I'm not playing the game - they are a part of me now). Unfortunately, its biggest pitfall is the lack of a main character and a boring main plot. The gameplay is solid, but I don't quite see the hype some other reviewers are giving it.  8/10

I'm not going to review this as in depth, because it's so similar to fallout 3, so most of what I said about that game already applies.  What I liked: +There's more weapons than in fallout 3.-- The addition of more weapons expands on what kinds of builds can be useful as you are leveling up. Although I will argue the game added too many weapons, which takes away some of the value that some weapons had from fallout 3. In other words, whereas one weapon was highly coveted before, now you can pick 1 of 4 weapons and be just as well off. Either way I see this as a plus.  +The faction system is a welcome addition to how you deal with groups of people -- It's a bit of a wonly feature, but it's nice to be able to build love/hate relationships with various groups in the wastes.  What I didn't like:  - There's a bit too many people, taking away some of the atmosphere that fallout 3 had. -- In fallout 3 there was a level of atmosphere added by the feeling that you were almost alone or that there weren't many people. Now however, it feels like you're never alone and that there are people everywhere. This creates a different feeling, which is for me, not as good as the original  - A lot of 'filler' quests. -- I can't tell you how many quests make you go and just talk to a guy, who tells you to talk to another guy, just to talk to another guy. The kicker, most of these guys involve fast traveling and forcing you to walk 3 miles to get to them. Really ruined my experience some days.  Despite some of the over-saturation of poor quests and bugs, I still recommend this game, just don't expect it to be as good as the original.

When I first started this game, I was overwhelmed:  - the open world - the diversity - the dialogues - the quests, not in the least the main quest - the choices - the companions and companion interaction - the survival aspect (playing on hardcore) - the overall atmosphere - the gunplay, being able to use both VATS and classic iron sights  Wow, just wow. This was great. Then came the second half of the game though:  - you suddenly notice every companion has the same routine of reluctantly offering you a quest for an upgrade, then afterwards the interaction falls completely flat - the world is open, but also relatively small, and you are steered quite strongly in a certain direction by means of e.g. very high tier enemies blocking shortcuts - survival comes down to simply chucking a seemingly endless supply of grilled squirels, even though the animals themselves are nowhere to be found (maybe because everybody eats them) - while you are still able to use VATS at higher levels, there is absolutely no reason to, as manual aiming is 200% more effective - around level 15, I pretty much stopped caring about what was happening in Vegas at all, because I allready was the king of the hill. As there are no stat or training restrictions on companions, even if you did not do very well for yourself skill or perk wise, with a laser sputnik and cowgirl in space marine armour throwing around nukes on your side, you do not even really need a weapon to begin with - the second half of the MQ is just on rails, though the rails might be cleverly concealed under some radioactive tumbleweeds. 'Get minor factions A, B, and C on your side', 'Go to X to do Y for either A, B, C', etc. In the end you are still going to X to do Y whatever choice you made. Some of the quest routes are in fact the exact same because route K does not have a designated choices, so you have to pretend to follow route L - the bugs,.. oh god,.. the bugs. The bugs basically went to the point that the last part of the MQ is totally unplayable without the console and a wiki or a walkthrough. I do not mind if a certain quest route is blocked by choices I (unknowingly) made prior, but I do mind if I miss out on fun game content because an essential NPC got run over by a two headed cow while I was binging whiskey at the other side of the world map. That is five years after release, without any mods or DLC's!  In conclusion I have to again emphasize that this game is great and that this game is fun, hence the frustration when for example a bug makes you miss out on some of it. However, there is also no denying the sheer quality difference between the first and the second half of the game, and that what we got was a rush job. Obsidian developped, had to develop this game in 18 months, and what they delivered can be called staggering. Where they failed it was due to the unrealistic expectations set by their own ambitions, which could be considered both commendable and painfull. It is painfull that this game never became what it should have been (though perhaps never could have been), but it still became better than most of anything else.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients:  1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs 3 tablespoons sugar 3 tablespoons melted butter 40 ounces softened cream cheese 1 cup sugar 3 tablespoons flour 1 tablespoon vanilla 1 cup sour cream 4 eggs  Directions: For The base:. If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375. Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on. Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter. For the batter:. Make sure everything is at room temperature. Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this. Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition. Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours. Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight. Release the sides of the springform. Eat.

In a story-driven, open-world RPG taking place in a post apocalyptic Mojave desert, you play as a courier seeking vengeance on the mysterious man who attempted to take your life. Pitted against many different biological and robotic horrors, the game exhibits a diverse amount of enemies to brutally disable, and even some helpful companions to help or hinder your journey along the way. In the eponymous New Vegas strip -- a patch of land almost completely untouched by the wars that were waged outside of it -- there resides an even more mysterious figure, name of Doctor Robert House; it's up to you to decide if he's as good as he says.  The combat is fun, utilizing VATS to lock on to certain bits of your opposer. The dialogue is well done, and meaningful in terms of revealing elements in the story of the events of the Fallout timeline and the Mojave. The weapons are diverse, moddable, and require constant repair and maintenance to keep at their fullest potential. The music makes you feel like you're living in the past, while you walk in the ruins of what was once a normal civilization far before your time. There are plenty of easter eggs and secrets to be found too.  If you enjoyed Fallout 3 and/or other RPGs, you'll enjoy New Vegas.

Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. Also, take the cumulative score with a grain of salt; it's just a numerical feeling about the game as a whole. That's part of why I do these subscores. Also, keep in mind that I'm not going off of school grade based rankings. A 5/10 denotes what I feel to be an average game. Likewise, 7/10 is a game that I think is pretty cool, and something that gets a 2/10 is near-abomination level. Pinning scores to an even further obfuscated rating scale is kinda senseless, but for the sake of my backloggery, I'll repeat again that 1.0-2.7 is a one-star game, 3.0-4.7 is a two-star game, 5.0-6.7, 7.0-8.7, and 9.0-10 are three, four, and five stars, respectively.  Additional Note: I'm reviewing the Ultimate Edition of the game, so I will be talking about the DLCs in this review.  Gameplay: If you're reading this, odds are that you already know something about the modern iterations of the Fallout series. If not, they're a hybrid FPS and RPG that actually works, unlike a lot of other games that try that design direction. Skill shooting is definitely rewarded and is very much welcome after my not so great experience with Borderlands (seriously, 600 bullets to the head from an SMG won't kill an enemy because NUMBERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!1), with repeated strikes to limbs crippling enemies, causing various ailments. While the system in this game is nowhere as deep or multi-faceted as 'true RPGs' like The Witcher or anything else like The Witcher, I do enjoy a streamlined apporach to action-y RPGs. Otherwise, it just gets in the way and you end up shooting 600 bullets into the head of an enemy and only end up doing about 1/3 of their health because your weapon doesn't have the appropriate numbers to counteract the enemy's numbers so your numbers (in health) get reduced until your other numbers (lives) gets reduced to zero. NUMBERS!!!!!!!!!!1  Of course, since this is a Fallout game, combat isn't always the most important aspect of the gameplay. It's important, but it's not stealing the spotlight. Exploration is a huge facet of the game as well, and there is a lot to explore here. If it weren't for my backlog of games, I'd probably spend another 60 hours exploring the wastes. Unfortunately, there are invisible walls placed sometimes in places where they make no sense whatsoever and can make exploring somewhat of a pain. I don't remember any of that happening in Fallout 3, but it has been a few years. Most of the time you can cut your own path through the wasteland and not have to worry about it, but it does happen from time to time and it can be rather frustrating.  One of the things that I noticed while playing through the game was that it didn't seem like it felt as profound as Fallout 3's adventure. Then, when I was thinking about it during one of my many restless nights (*shakes fist at insomnia*), I realized why it was: the game is just offering choice. Choice that I don't recall being present in 3 (other than a last minute ultimatum, of course). Your choices do actually have some impact on what goes on at the end, with certain choices pleasing some while stepping on the feet of others. It really does help the game feel that much more alive, and even though it may not feel as grand an adventure as Fallout 3's, the choice you have (with regards to everything, really) is a much more welcome addition than just a longer journey.  Alright, let's talk about the DLC. Play Old World Blues; skip the rest. If you really haven't been sated by Old World Blues, play Lonesome Road. Dead Money (Sierra Madre Grand Opening) is just abysmal and predicated upon a really flimsy plot device that essentially removes every aspect of player choice given to you throughout the game. Honest Hearts starts on an escort mission, so I didn't even bother continuing beyond that introduction. At least I was able to finish Lonesome Road, even if Deathclaws ruined my day by being honestly really OP for the area. Old World Blues is simply fantastic, though, and includes something that made me really happy at the end: A BOSS FIGHT! This game doesn't actually have any boss fights, which was incredibly disappointing for someone who likes boss fights, but at least Old World Blues brought one.   Overall, I had a lot of fun with this game, and while I don't think the Dead Money or Honest Hearts DLCs are that great, they're not enough of a reason not to pick up the Ultimate Edition of this game. Old World Blues is more than good enough of an addition to make it worthwhile, as well as some of the more minor DLCs. 8/10.  Story: Much like I talked about in the Gameplay section, the biggest difference between this and 3 is that this one offers a lot more choices as to how the story goes. Admittedly, not all of these choices have necessarily profound consequences, but they do at least change the world in some minor way. Also, choosing the fate of New Vegas isn't necessarily as grand or impacting a choice as the big decision in 3, but again, the element of choice is what brings this game to par with 3. The writing for the main game is still great and the main characters are all believable, flawed, and rife with their own agendas for the fate of New Vegas.   Again, I'll dedicate a paragraph to the DLCs. Old World Blues is overall quite alright, if a bit groan-worthy with its tongue-through-cheek-and-through-another-person's-cheeks humor. Plus, that DLC has the world's longest expository dump. No seriously, it took about 30 minutes of dialogue to get to actual gameplay in Old World Blues. So yeah, that wasn't the greatest. Lonesome Road was... kinda pretentious, honestly. It tried to do the Spec Ops thing where- actually, you probably know about that. At least ED-E was adorable throughout. As mentioned earlier, I abandoned ship on Dead Money since the whole basis of the game was really flimsy and the one character I met (God aka Dog. Yeah, we get it, guys) really wasn't all that interesting. Honest Hearts didn't grab my attention enough with the opening scene; it might be good, but everyone kept dying, so I didn't bother anymore.   Overall, the writing for the main game may not be as grand of an adventure as the prior games, and the writing in the DLCs can be... not so great at times, but that element of choice more than makes up for it. 8/10.  Graphics: This is gonna be another one of those games that may not look so great in ten or so years. It looks good enough now, but I have a feeling that looking back, this game will look about as good as Quake 2 on the N64 does today. However, to be brutally honest, an art style isn't the biggest culprit for what makes this game look not so great at times. It's the technical aspects. For starters, there is a RIDICULOUS amount of pop-in, with one of the most noticeable examples being whenever I looked down the sights for a pistol, my left hand took a half second to render. Also, many objects in the wasteland pop in at a relatively close range, even with all settings maxed out. There's also some texture clipping as well, specifically with some not-so-subtle clashes of fake environment skyboxex and actual environment models. It kinda ruins the atmosphere seeing a hill in the distance flicker like a rave. The game does run fine on my GTX 760 at 1080p Ultra settings, but I just wish they had spent some more time working on the technical aspects of the graphics engine. 2/5.  *apparently I've ran out of space, so I'll continue in a comment. First time that's happened.*

This game needs to be in any rpg lovers collection. The game runs just fine on almost anything, and if the graphics seem a little bit dated the moddding community has created numerous graphical improvements for the game. I have played 60 hours of this game and am still going strong. The main story line is very very short and can be completed in only a few hours, but this game is more about exploration and taking up side quests. Since the reputation system has made a return you now have a reason to replay this game at least 3 or 4 times just to see what different reputations with different communities are like. Also, when you finally exaust all of the Vanilla content there are 4 packs of quest DLC which will give you plenty of extra playtime. After you blast through all of that then you are left with the amazing modding community that alone has ammounted for more than half of my playtime. Now there are a few cons with this game. The biggest one would be that the engine is terrible and you will have quite a few crashes every now and again, but like the rest of the problems with this game mods have fixed the majority of issues will be fixed. So in all I would have to say that if you are looking for a good sequel to Fallout 3 or any of Interplays original Fallout titles that won't be found here. I'm gonna be honest and say for a couple of years I didn't appreciate New Vegas that much, Fallout 3 was my first Fallout game and I have played Fallout 1 and 2, while I appreciate those game for what they where, they were not my cup of tea. Now New Vegas I had a problem with at first because it felt to different from Fallout 3 (to me it did), and also I played it on release so I experienced a lot of bugs and crashes, the first time I played it I played the NCR rout thinking that was the best one, the truth was I felt empty afterwards, I felt like I didn't accomplish anything, and the only DLC I had for it was Dead Money and Honest Hearts, I wasn't impressed with them. So flash forward years later and I buy this game on sale, I let it sit in my library for a while until I feel like shooting it up, I decided to go the Wild Card rout this time, and taking that rout changed my whole perspective of this game, I met many of the interesting factions, I did more interesting side quests, what New Vegas succeeded at the most was that Role-Playing, yeah for a RPG it gets the Role-Playing spot on, every side you choose has a consequence, you can change how companions think, it's fantastic. The gameplay also improves a lot from Fallout 3 as well, having iron sights without having to install mods, having weapon mods, different ammo, it really does help. I've played through Dead Money again and I learned that it was a DLC trying to be different from other DLC's, you're supposed to feel weak and helpless in it, even with a high level character, Honest Hearts looks fantastic in my opinion, as someone who went to Zion once I have to say, they nailed down the atmosphere, and the Burnt Man's tale is simply incredible writing, possibly the best writing in the entire game. I've yet to play the rest of the DLC (Old War Blues, Lonesome Road) but I can say that I'm very excited to play them! In my past reviews with Bethesdia games I always mention the mods, and while NV has amazing mods I don't think that should be enough to judge a game, you judge a game on how it was originally made. Overall I've grown to love New Vegas, possibly more than Fallout 3, while Fallout 3 is still an amazing game I feel like New Vegas gets everything right, it fixes any problems Fallout 3 had and adds more, the game isn't trying to be Fallout 4, it's trying to be a spin off of Fallout 3 while improving. Do I recommend this game? Holy hell yes I do

The Fallout games are one of my favorite game series I've played. Playing all the main series Fallout games Fallout New Vegas is a return to it's roots in the original two games. Fallout New Vegas plays almost exactly like Fallout 3 with the additon of iron sights on weapons, which if you prefere not to use can be disabled. There was also a crashing problem which cursed the earlier patchs of the game. This is mostly worked out but the engine may destablize if you enjoy modding your game.  The main storyline of Fallout New Vegas isn't too interesting. The story starts with the player being shot and burried in a shallow grave in the desert. By chance your survive, thanks to a robco securitron and a wastleland doctor, and set off in a quest for revenge which in turn causes you to be recognized by all the major fractions in the area causing you to be the man/women on the frontline in the coming war. This story isn't as interesting to play as it may sound however, but thats not what we're here for. You can play for over 200 hours on a single charter in the ultimate edition and still not beat the game once because of how many things there are to do. The quests and story can have a decent sense of moral ambiguity, which is one of the things I really enjoyed in the older Fallouts. The player is also given a greater feeling of choice and impact through having more options of how to deal with situations and having a greater veriaty of people in the Mojave desert.  I am also willing to factor mods into this review due to people making the intallation of them being as easy as a download and a few clicks. The Fallout modding community has created amazing quests and adventures that I feel do nothing but benefit the game. Just be careful with mods because it may destablize and already sensitive engine.

(9/10) A very compelling game that takes a while to get started. Once you're in you're hooked and can spend countless hours completing quests and finding new loot and interesting characters.  DLC:  Dead Money: (5.5/10) Just overall very aggrevating and has way too big of a difficulty spike half way through. On the plus side it does have a few unique melee weapons and some pretty charismatic characters.  Honest Hearts: (9/10) Probably my personal favourite of the dlc for this game. It unlocks a beautiful new area to explore and unlocks more background info on the burned man. Also has a few unique weapons and some armor depending on how you play it.  Old World Blues: (8.75/10) Almost as enjoyable as Honest Hearts. I think i like the previous one more just due to the environment it unlocked. Old World Blues unlocks a new place as well, but its not quite as compelling and has no real connection to the main game. On the plus side, tons of crazy new weapons and a wicked sense of humour.  Lonesome Road: (7.5/10) Probably the most impressive dlc graphically and a lot of the scenery reminded me of the wastes in Fallout 3. The biggest problem this one has is how short it is. I think i spent the least time on this one and it was a little too linear compared to the previous two. There are also much tougher enemies so don't bother playing this one til you're at least level 25-30. This is probably the most compelling story of all the dlcs, but really only has two characters and is just too short.  Overall: (9.2/10) With the exception of Dead Money the ultimate edition is an absolute must buy especially because it is so cheap now and you can get so much bang for your buck as far as gameplay time. Never reaches the heights of greatness Fallout 3 hit, but this is none the less a great game even if it is quite a bit buggy.

I loved the Fallout Series, and played Fallout 1, Fallout 2 including Tactics, was quite entertaining, and then New Vegas was introduced to us... Multiplayer seems to be where gaming is, and if all they care about is money, you can see why Artificial Intelligent programming has slacked off severely, and the AI has become a placeholder for a human controller, less programming, less bugs to fix, with more money coming in.  That said... The game was very fun, desppite the AI stupidity, and how easy it was to kill them, especially with the VAT system in place. Plenty of weapons in the game, and places to see and there is always a bit of humor in the Fallout franchise, which keeps me coming back for more...  Con's Once you beat the campagin there's no real reason to keep playing the game, since the campaign will pretty much take you every where causing you to discover everything there is to discover... Where the game falls short is it's using the game platform to milk DLC additions to the game, I always thought this was a shady money making gimmick, so no longer do gaming company's have to provide you with an optimal gaming experience, when they can give you 'enough', and charge for the rest in DLC. Thats my beef with these one time giant gaming company's, that get you addicted to their games, then sucker you into the DLC.... Everyone's jumping on the bandwagon, just about...   All in all, the game was fun, and is worth a buy, because it will take you a long time to complete the campaign, and if you opt in to buy the DLC, will provide a few hours more game time after you've completed the campaign... .After which it'll sit in your steam account never to be touched again... The story line and those embeded along they way go very deep and you'll want to try and understand all the sotries. I was very much satisfied with what I could learn in this fictional universe. Wandering the wasteland that is the Mojave was a road completely full of life, and holding just as much loot. Then there's the DLC, each one has at least one moral to them, such as Lonsome Road and Ulysses's statement on how our we must use our pasts to affect our futures(It was a bit more complex when he says it, and it sounds so much grander.) Outside the morals the DLC are just as extensive as the main questline, if not even deeper at time explaining parts of the main story. Playing all of them was like playing a different game at times if you were able to really get into their finer points. Fallout: New Vegas is a Run'n'Gun game, a loot fest, a military operation, or it can be a full fledged RPG with all of these aspects; it's completely up to you. There are very few limits and you'll be playing for hours, I highly recommend you give this game a try.

Grab a modern Fallout fan and ask them what their favorite Fallout game is and chances are that they'll say, 'Fallout 3.' That's all well and good, but New Vegas provides what F3 lacked: strong writing, quest design, memorable characters, deeper equipment customization, and real character creation. If you're anything like me, the journey is just as important as the destination, maybe more so. Fallout 3 strikes that excellent post-apocalyptic sandbox feeling, while New Vegas provides a meaty foundation of lore, storytelling, and a real sense of being just an ordinary person who becomes caught up in a clash of social and political upheaval.   You play Fallout 3 for a sense of complete open freedom and empowerment as you roleplay.   You play New Vegas to participate in the world around you. The dialogue choices matter, your skills feel interwoven with all aspects of gameplay, and finally the karma system feels a bit more dynamic. People will not all love you, and they won't necessarily be wrong for doing so. There are shades of gray cast throughout every character and quest, and this is where New Vegas shines bright as the radiation scorched Strip that serves as its centerpiece. The world of New Vegas feels alive, and you get to weave one hell of a rags to riches story for yourself. One person really can make all the difference when all of the forces at work are balanced against each other on a knife's edge.   Unfortunately, it isn't without its problems. New Vegas suffers visually by rehashing Fallout 3's engine, and even after extensive efforts to patch bugs, they still have a tendency to rear their ugly coded heads. Also, as mentioned above, New Vegas is not a free and open sandbox like Fallout 3, which will be jarring for some. While it has many aspects of a sandbox, it is at its heart a game with a story to tell. It's a story you get to be part of and in large part design alongside the game, but you're ultimately headed where the developers want you to go.   To end on a semi-pretentious note: New Vegas is the more mature Fallout experience. It tackles far more interesting subject matter and ideas of personal identity than Fallout 3 could ever hope to. The levels of customization and character creation are much improved over Fallout 3, and it makes for a phenomenal roleplaying game. After experiencing all the lights of Vegas, Fallout 3 still seems vast and free to me, but also just a bit more empty.

This is arguably the best RPG to have ever of come into existance. Does taking over the entire Mojave, killing Ghouls (the equivalent of zombies), modding, and an immersive story interest you? Then this is the game for you.   The story starts you out as a courier who had to deliver a platinum chip. Turns out, the chip is more than just platinum; on it is something that plays a vital role in the future of the post apocalyptic Las Vegas and Hoover Dam. The rest is history; your history to be exact.  The modding capabilities of this game are outrageous; it nearly rivals the sandbox that is Garry's Mod in this aspect. Once you complete the game, I highly recommend you try out Project Brazil. Project Brazil is a community developed mod for FNV that introduces a new map the size of Fallout 3, and a vault that I dare say is better than any of the other vaults that Bethesda themselves have brought into existance. I would however, like to point out that Project Brazil is STILL under development even though it came out back in 2012. Unfortunitely, they decided to drop the development of module 3 at the end of 2013 (I think...) and 2014 was an overall slow year for the development of the project. So here we are in early 2015, and just recently (back in March) the development revived to preside the anticipated launch of Fallout 4 next year.  FNV is an overall stunning game; even five years later. I couldn't recommend this game more, but you will need a lot of free time to actually get into it just like most good games. It's hard to get into if you don't have time, so for people without a lot of time, this isn't for you.

Easily one of the best Role Playing Games I've had the pleasure of becoming immersed in. A fantasticly crafted world with incredibly entertaining characters and interesting and fun quest design is where this game shines brigtest. While it's occasionally held down by clunky melle combat, the V.A.T.S system is very entertaining to use, and can make skirmishes feel far more cinematic and exciting. My only REAL problem with the role playing is the way karma works. Often times the game makes it's choices far too black-and-white; I can only recall one quest where the main choice at the end actually felt like a moral dilema, rather than most quest that go something like, 'Murder person, get new gun. Don't murder person, get a few caps.' Scenarios like this is where I felt the dev's forgoed the oppourtunity to make interesting moral and ethical choices like those present in the Mass Effect games. Instead, we far too often simply get a 'good' and 'bad' choice, not an actual issue to contemplate.  And yet despite all of this, the characters and quest design really made up for what I felt the moral portion of the game lacked. So, so many of the major characters manage to be both funny and interesting; Lilly, Arcade Gannon, Veronica and The King were some of my favorite characters throughout the game. The quests offer a combination of simple tasks and mundane chores, as well as exciting romps and fully fleshed out mini-storylines. 'Come Fly With Me,' for example, is a quest where you're tasked with helping build rockets to launch a cult of ghouls (Heavily irradiated humans) to a destination their leader promises will be a safe haven for their kind. In another, 'GI Blues,' you help a crime lord, who also happens to be an Elvis Impersonator, sort out difficulties with a new militant group taking refuge in his territory. They all seem interesting, and while many have underwhelming rewards, the fact that you get to take part in such a fun adventure seems like a reward in itself.  I highly, highly reccomend this game to fans of Western RPG's, especially if you loved Oblivion. A good sense of humor, fantastic characters, and a rich, mysterious wasteland to explore will have you playing for hours.
