Back when it was first announced and then released, all you would have to do is briefly mention Fallout: New Vegas and have them make some sort of comment such as, 'You mean Fallout 3.5?' or, 'It should have just been an expansion to Fallout 3!' and so on. People were so quick to see a new idea and a story different from that of the Lone Wanderer's that they didn't want to see it for what it was at all. People were so quick to look at a game that wasn't as backed by Bethesda as the former was and say the absolute worst about it in order to hold on to whatever they felt for the previous game, and for a long time I was one of those people myself.  But after a while I realized it wasn't fair of me to blindly judge a game I'd never played, never as much as watched gameplay for, never tried to educate myself on, and continue to stay stuck in oblivion about something that could turn out to be a lot better than any of us expected.  So I picked up a copy of New Vegas, and that was exactly the case. It was   better   than I thought it would be, all of the assumptions I'd built up being completely washed away by a game that should be getting so much more credit than it does to this day still. Courier Six isn't the Lone Wanderer, nor do they feel that way when switching between the two games, they're a fresh new persona to take on and it feels exactly how it should, like something new. After a tragic turn in Six's job to deliver a package to New Vegas, you start to realize just how much more freedom you're given in this game, compared to Fallout 3. Rather than being flat out told who was bad and who you were supposed to show sympathy for, who you were supposed to dislike, etc; your actions actually carry   weight   with other factions, cities, groups, individuals and they   will   be aware of what you do, and what you have already done. It really feels like a nation split up into parts, and once you start making waves for whatever purpose or person you decide to make them for, if not yourself, those parts   will   be watching you, and depending on what you do, they may or may not be happy about it.  New Vegas in my opinion, feels so much more lively than Fallout 3 did. From the very beginning, you're presented with a group of varying people that have their own quirks and as a whole, have their own issues that they wouldn't mind having you help out with, it feels like you aren't just given a quest by any of these people in any of these settlements that you do simply to get out of the way and receive some little reward for it, it feels more like there's actual consequences weighing on how you decide to handle each situation and majority of those consequences play out in the ending scenes. 'Treat others how you want to be treated' can be applied to most, if not all of the choices you can decide to make in this game. If you're an ♥♥♥ to one faction, expect that faction to be just as big of an ♥♥♥ to you back. If you're a saint, people might just help you out more than you expect.  While the storyline grants its freedoms throughout every quest for every faction, the story itself immerses you far quicker than it might've in F3. The opening cutscene fills you with a sense of confusion, a desire for explanation, and just a little bit of a craving for revenge for yourself and your Courier. Each build-up to key points in the story is given to you in a rather fulfilling way, like you've spent just the right amount of time looking for this person, you've travelled just the right length of land to reach this place and you're one step closer to the final battle for Hoover Dam, which decides the fate of the Mojave, and who holds control of it after you've picked your allies. There are a few instances where things could be put together more neatly, but it can be easily looked over by the rest of the game.  Most of the scenery -- and all of the combat -- stick to the roots created in Fallout 3, the same barren and dangerous environment that's supposed to keep you on your toes, and does. V.A.T.S is always there if you need it and the option for true iron sights can make you feel more like you're actually aiming rather than repeatedly mashing buttons while turning around trying to shoot whatever you're trying to shoot, but I found it was more of a burden than any more immersive sort of experience. The combat is the same as it was and S.P.E.C.I.A.L and a perk every two levels returns just as usual, featuring a lot more perks to increase your carry weight which helps out extensively when you're out scavenging for junk.  Just as the storyline is fulfilling, the DLC does not slip up one bit. I'd recommend getting every one, and playing them in order, since the story they create when put together forms an experience unlike any other I've seen in any downloadable content, and while you may not enjoy it the first playthrough, each one will grow on you. Unlike F3's DLCs, the ones in New Vegas give you insight on your Courier, and how one of their choices before the game affected the life of someone you will hear about in both the DLCs and the vanilla game itself; and subsequently how they devoted a great portion of their life to following you, eventually deciding to let you come to them. The build-up to this storyline is unbelievable, as well, truly a plot worth witnessing and coming to grips with just how easily one decision can start a chain of events.  This is an open-world game, and with all open-world games, there's always the typical graphical glitches, the hilarious ragdoll-looking bugs and the less-than-enjoyable occasional patches of lag and crashes, though it's hardly any level that makes you unable to play this game for hours on end, with all of the places available for you to discover (Vaults, too!) you're bound to stumble across something that catches your interest and takes some of your time if you're not looking to finish the main storyline right away. In short, there's something to do for everyone, heroes and villains of the Mojave alike.  New Vegas has become the love of my video game life, with over 100+ hours invested into Couriers of all types on the PS3 and now getting wrapped up into it all over again with already 30+ hours as I write this after only having it bought for the PC just a few days ago, if you're after a post-apocalyptic RPG to tide you over as long as it takes for Fallout 4 to rear its head, this'd be it. It's a game inviting to those looking for a story, a shooter, a game with enjoyable DLC (in ALL of the DLC) and a game to mod, that's what you're after. Give it a chance and it just might surprise you.

Fallout: New Vegas is a vast, expansive game that evolves upon many of the concepts and mechanics in Fallout 3, whilst reviving ideas from the previous games in the series and incorporating everything into a cohesive, if somewhat overwhelming whole. After playing for over 150 hours, I have still left vast swathes of the wasteland unexplored, hours of dialogue unheard, quests unresolved... The game can be completed in a variety of ways - from indulging in the somewhat masochistic hardcore mode which mostly serves as an annoyance - to the 'speedrun' approach of following only the main quest line and neglecting the game's various attempts to distract you with side quests and the wasteland's mysteries.  Mechanically, New Vegas grants the player substantial freedom to play the game in exactly the way they wish, and offers multiple solutions to most quests and situations - such as diffusing conflict with your speech skill, assassinating an enemy with a sneak kill, or equipping heavy armour and weaponry, and wiping out an enemy settlement. The game will impose consequences for your actions - such as being hunted by assassins when you make yourself the enemy of a faction - or receiving regular gifts by becoming their ally. The factions have their own allegiances, desires and advantages - allowing you to play them against each other and directly influence the wasteland's political landscape.  As with other games of the 'Elder Scrolls format' - there are a number of issues with npcs that distract from the experience and somewhat disrupt the realism of the experience: the conversations that freeze the rest of the game world break immersion somewhat when another character can be seen frozen mid-walk in the background, or the fading-out of characters as they pass between areas. These issues are fortunately largely obviated by the excellent voice acting and authentic, well-characterised conversation trees. There is a staggering amount of dialogue - with all of the major characters having their own identity, style and humorous quirks.  The last major element of the game worthy of discussion is the combat system, which is weighty and satisfying - heavy weapons can send corpses flying though the air, or exploding into a hilariously-gruesome shower of blood, eyeballs and meaty chunks. Laser and plasma weapons can reduce enemies to piles of dust or goo, guns can be loaded with a variety of ammunition types to suit different threats, melee fighters can learn special close-combat moves, and virtually every weapon has some exotic unique variation, or a number of modifications that can be applied.  I would recommend this game strongly - for its flexible storytelling for the RPG fan - for its hilariously gratuitous action for the FPS fan - and for its sheer enormity for those who enjoy an adventure.

Fallout: New Vegas is one of the best games I've ever had the pleasure to experience. I use the term 'experience' as opposed to 'play' in this case because that's exactly what Fallout: New Vegas is, an experience! You ultimately decide the fate of the Mojave wasteland, and the people and locations you come across throughout the game force my hand in congratulating the developers at Bethesda (not that I was reluctant in the first place!).  Fallout: New Vegas has one of the most enticing stories that I've been able to uncover in a game, it's vast plot adds to the already humongous database that makes up Fallout's lore. Now, this review can't all be praise for this game, right? Right. I will focus on the most prominent problem that unfortunately plagues Fallout: New Vegas. The glitches. While there are some glitches that I have come across that I could solve using console commands, there are many major glitches that I have come across that required tedious research and numerous trial and error attempts to fix. Some of these major glitches include: -Freezing on start-up -Broken character interactions -Missing characters/Impossible to complete quests I'm sure there are plenty of mods that can fix many of the problems I have come across, not unlike Skyrim. Now, to move back onto the praise... The DLC, my God! The DLC! The Downloadable content for this game is among the most enjoyable, maybe even the best DLC I have ever downloaded for a game. All of the stories are tied together in one way or another (with the exception of Honest Hearts, I haven't found any links to/from that one) and they have all made a lasting impression on me that I'm sure will last a long time, for better (Lonesome Road) or worse (Dead Money) ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) All joking aside, the DLC presented a welcome challenge and a unique story. Definitely worth the cost!  Overall, Fallout: New Vegas is possibly the best single player game I have experienced in a long time. I would recommend it to anyone who happens to be a fan of Bethesda's other works/Fallout 3.

I'm not going to lie, this is the most awesome game I have ever played. I both have it on the PC and the Xbox and played all the missions on them, even the DLCs. If you like a survival game where you are on a borderline between civilization and anarchy, this game is suited for you. I recommend downloading all the DLCs for this game as you will get more options to work with. Now note that when playing Fallout games, your decisions will alter the ending in some way. So before you beat the game, make sure you have done EVERY mission or you won't get a complete ending.  Now for those who are thinking of buying this game, your character's development is very specific. It is similar to 'Fallout 3' but slightly modified. The actions and reactions you make in the plot of the game is determined by your raw power and skills. Raw power being S.P.E.C.I.A.L.: Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility, and Luck. I recommend maxing out one of these raw power abilities as you will need to have a strength in something to avoid dying constantly. Now you get numerous skills, which are indirectly determined by S.P.E.C.I.A.L. For example, having a high level in intelligence will give you tagged skills in Science, Medicine, and Repair. The higher the skill, the more your life is made easier when the situation demands them. The final stage of character development are perks, which are made available to you depending on your raw powr and skills. These perks will open back doors to handling situations and benefit your chance of survival in some way. For example, getting the 'Cannibal' perk will allow you to eat human corpses when food is scarce, but at a cost.  Just to let you know, there is a 'Hardcore Mode'. In Hardcore mode, you have to worry about food, water, and sleep. Some aspects of the game will get harder with hardcore mode is one. For example, healing will slowly regenerate your health rather than replenishing it instantly. Healing crippled limbs may determine the difference between life and death, as you will encounter some enemies you need to run away from. Some enemies, however, will only sign your death certificate regardless. Luckily for you, you can craft all sorts of goodies using the appropriate workstation. Find a workbench, reloading bench, and a campfire if you are planning on making some homemade goods.  Now with the aspects of the game covered, the one thing you must know about the Fallout game is that it's full of bugs and coding errors. They're not straight out and obvious, but they will crawl out of the woodwork to haunt you. Some of these bugs and glitches can be fixed using the console command, but this option is not available to you if you decide to play the console version of the game. I stopped playing the PC version of this game long ago because the constant crashes and freezes that keep happening on my computer. I would recommend playing the console version of the game as it is more stable, however the bugs and glitches are slightly more unusual, so save often.  TL;DR:  The game is great, giving all sorts of aspects of survival and danger of a post-apocalyptic world; but be ready for the occasional game freeze and the annoying bugs.

TL;DR version? If you played Fallout 3, it's more of the same, only this time with a better story and ending, more loot, and a whole bunch of new places to explore. Definitely worth if you're a fan, and make sure to get the DLC packs as well!  The long version?  Well first off like I just said, the game is identical to FO3 in many ways, but they've added little things here and there that make the experience more in-depth. Stuff like aiming down the ironsights, weapon mods, more companions with fleshed out backstories and unique traits that won't die on you by accident, casinos and gambling, a pretty decent card game called Caravan, a new faction system involving the New California Republic, Caesars Legion and Mr. House, in place of the FO3's karma system (which is still there, but not terribly important anymore). The other big addition is Hardcore mode, which makes the game more challenging by involving new stats like hunger, thirst, sleep, more difficult to heal injuries, less item carrying space, permanent companion deaths, etc. I tried it out and liked the extra challenge... until I realized that your companion deaths are permanent too. And given how dumb the AI can be at times... yeah, too much hassle right there.   The plot is much more nuanced than what FO3 had. While the NCR ultimately does tend to be the better group of the three due to making an effort to integrate the locals instead of forcefully removing them from their lands or outright slaughtering them, they've still got their grey areas and a few shady characters who lack scruples and are willing to give the axe to anyone who doesn't play nice... Colonel Munroe comes to mind. Kinda difficult to empathize with Caesar's Legion though, since they're basically a bunch of enslaving technophobics who view women and people of lower castes as property and little else, and their questline feels shorter and rushed compared to the others.   The increased max character level does mean that you can beef up a bit more, and it doesn't make the Raiders and other minor groups crazy-overpowered to compensate, the DLC expansion areas (ESPECIALLY Lonesome Road) being the exceptions. Takes much longer to reach the max level as well, but you'll definitely reach it long before completing more than half of the game.  The glitches are definitely a problem; a lot of the bigger ones at release have been fixed, but there are still a ton of bugged quests and items out there; a good example being the 'Beyond the Beef' quest which I'd recommend avoiding entirely if possible. You will probably need to download a fanpatch or two if you really want to fix it.

Hello there, I don't know why the hell you would need to be looking at any reviews for this, this is  Fallout , is it not?  But anyway I will say that this was my first experience with  Fallout , on PS3 however.  If you are thinking of buying this game on a console be warned: STAY AWAY!  The game is great but the console port of this game is broken, and to make it worse the only bugs they fixed on consoles were the ones that were at least entertaining, leaving the ones that freeze/crash the game alone for some reason.  If you haven't noticed I'm double spacing each individual sentence so that this has some consistency with my other reveiws, and to ensure that it is up to par with all other non-joke reveiws in terms of length.  I have played all the Bethesda  Fallout  games now (no I have not had the pleasure of experiencing  Fallout 1, 2, Tactics, BoS  or  Van Buren ) and I think this one is my favorite in terms of style.  I don't think any of the other  Fallout s let you be a Cowboy/girl sporting a classic dueling revolver or leaver-action repeater.  You can also have sex with a guy who previously shot you in the face and buried you in a shallow grave, I don't know who would want to do that but its possible (I'm pretty sure that only female characters have this option for obvious reasons).  The character facial customization leaves something to be desired though, when I played this on the PS3 I tried to make my character look like me only to end up with a cowboy-Elvis-cardboard box hybrid.  On Steam my character is much more aesthetically pleasing but I think it could still be better.  I should probably start talking more about the gameplay and choices since I'm pretty sure that's what most of you came here for.  Of the three  Fallout  games I've played, this one seems to have the most choice in terms of plot development, unlike  Fallout 3  (I don't know how 4 ends yet) you are not forced to ally with the Brotherhood of Steel, and the Enclave aren't even present anymore ( Fallout's 2  and  3  will explain this), instead you have the New Calafornia Republic and Caesar's (pronunced  Kysar 's) Legion.  Due to time restraints during this game's development the Legion is not seen nearly as much as the NCR, though their role in the main story is equally as important as the NCR's.  These time constraints also likelly explain why the console port is so broken.  The gunplay in this game is superior to that of  Fallout 3 , as you can actually look down the iron sights in combat.  If your character also turns out looking not at all that bad I would also recommend playing this in 3rd preson, I really like looking at the backside of my character while I shoot Viper Gunslinger heads off for some reason.  In this game you have four possible main story arcs, each with multiple different endings, you can side with the NCR, Caesar's Legion, New Vegas or none of them and create an independent Vegas.  That adds a whole new level of RPG-ness to the game (I'm pretty sure  Fallout 3  does not feature nearly as many endings as this game).  V.A.T.S is still just as useful and unique as it ever was.  I'm sort of mentioning everything I think I need to talk about (why did I write talk because you are reading this and not actually hearing me speak) at random here.  The perk and skill system is still present and not dumbed-down like it is in  Fallout 4  (I know a lot of people would want to know about that, although a more 'streamlined' character building system has never bothered me).  Karma is still present and Reputation has been reintroduced ( Fallout 3  did not have reputation and  Fallout 4  has neither).  The only bug I've encounterd (in the STEAM version, not the PS3 as there are many, many game-breaking bugs in that version) is that occasionally when I reload a save the loading screen goes on forever.  That only happens SOMETIMES, not often enough for me to really be bothered by it.  I did not have to fix the game the same way I had to with  Fallout 3  on my laptop (yes I'm running this stuff on a LAPTOP), which runs Windows 8 (no Microsoft I will not re-enable the auto-update 'feature' and get Windows 10).  By the way after I fixed  Fallout 3  that game started running magically, and I haven't encountered a single bug.  Also the guy who shoots you in the head that you can later choose to have sex with is voiced by Matthew Perry who played Chandler on  Friends .  This game also features gambling (you should have already guessed that), but sadly there is no Texas Holdem', only Blackjack, slots and Roulette.  I would have thought that Obsidian Entertainment would have been able to realize that there is nothing more satisfying than winning a game of virtual Texas Holdem' in a sandbox game.  That was like my third favorite part of  Red Dead Redemption  after the story and gameplay.  Instead you have this new card game called Caravan that I tried to play but really didn't find that fun or self explanatory.  But at least the amazing and often-unusual sidequests more than make up for the amount of time I would have spent playing Texas Holdem' if it were included.  The DLC for this game is also amazing, as per usual with any RPG publised by Bethesda.  I recommend that you buy the Ultimate Edition, as it is well worth the price of admission just to hear a Brain-in-a-jar mistaken your toes male jenitles.  Oh, and all the companions are awesome, I know for a fact that you will at least recruit Veronica as she is one of the first potential companions you will encounter.  And if you are disappointed by a lack of Dogmeat, ED-E will more than make up for it.  And unlike  Fallout 3 , the only times your companions can die is if you are on a high difficulty or if you decide to kill them yourself for some reason.  Veronica! Don't charge at that Deathclaw! What are your, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!? I guarantee that its natural claws are far more powerful than that pneumatic gauntlet you're wearing!  Running into a bunker to get away from a group of rogue palidins that are way stronger than you only to get attacked by everyone inside for no reason and then accidentally tell Veronica to sit still while she gets attacked and you are forced to flee leaving her there finding that the rogue palidins outside are no longer hostile towards you while everyone inside still wants you dead and then you eventually come back to rescue Veronica later with a missile launcher killing several of her family members and making her angry with you and then you realize that there are companion dismissal termials scattered in convienient locations throughout the map that would have sent her back to where you first met her if you used it/10

Ah, Fallout: New Vegas. One of the best games that I've ever played. While Fallout 3 was an FPS with RPG elements, this is an RPG with FPS elements. Sorry for just gushing like that, but what can I say? This is a fantastic game; huge improvement over Fallout 3, only lacking in atmosphere, enviroment/map, and graphics. Stability issues are also a big no-no, so you should definitly go out and get the New Vegas Anti Crash mod right off the bat. (along with many other fantastic mods: it's a whole new world out there!)  I'd recommend it to anyone, although I feel Fallout 3 is a better choice to start out on, since it's mechanics are far more simplistic.

New Vegas brings back the tang and twang of Southwestern Americana that was lacking in its immediate predecessor, along with a host of gameplay improvements. There's a strange quality to the writing and world building that is unmistakbly the work of Chris Avellone and co. The retrofuturistic radio stations return with incredibly catchy tunes from ye olde pop standards, blues and jazz. The weird locales and weirdos that call them home are some of the weirdest yet. Most memorable are the new cast of companions: desperate, tragic characters that are believable and more than just mules with pre-recorded dialogue. This focus on the (in)humanity of the wasteland brings us back to the political focus of the plot, which asks players to ultimately make a decision about the fate of a pocketful of civilization. It's not a world-spanning, world-saving RPG. A much more worthy successor to the first two Fallout games than Fallout 3 ever was. If you're looking for more like Fallout 3, you should probably look elsewhere. Fallout: New Vegas uses the same engine as Fallout 3, but the world is much more faithful to the original games, and the story line is much more complex and politically-focused. New Vegas is one of the most ambitious RPGs ever made, forcing the player to juggle a myriad of interconnected quests and objectives in a complex web of politics. It is up to the player to decide the fate of the Mojave Wasteland by choosing one of four factions to side with in the battle for Hoover Dam. The game is highly replayable because, with the exception of the early game, siding with different factions results in highly varied objectives and outcomes. The game isn't perfect, but it is a very engrossing experience, with Obsidian putting much more thought into the actual role-playing aspect of the game than Bethesda did with Fallout 3.  The DLC for Fallout: New Vegas is mostly a series of independent quests tangentially connected to the main game with an underlying storyline that gets rapped up in the final piece of DLC: Lonesome Road. Do yourself a favor and play the DLC areas in the order in which they were released: Dead Money-->Honest Hearts-->Oldworld Blues-->Lonesome Road. The conclusion of Lonesome Road will feel much more satisfying and personal if you pay attention to the details about Ulysses scattered throughout the main game and the other DLC. It's unfortunate that an important storyline that was clearly planned from the game's original release had to be hidden away in DLC that very few people have played.

Fallout 3 or Fallout New Vegas?  I see a lot of people asking about if they should play Fallout 3 first, or Fallout: New Vegas. I went through this dillemma myself. I chose to buy Fallout: New Vegas.  Let me first give you a brief summary about the two games: Fallout 3: You are a vault dweller. Your father has left the vault for an unknown reason. You go after him and enter the Capital Wasteland. You're main goal is to find your father again. Fallout: New Vegas: You are a courier who had to deliver a package, but in the middle of your journey you were shot in the head by a member of the Chairmen (one of the families of the Strip). You wake up after being healed by an old man and you track him down. There is also a war going on in the Mojave Wasteland between the NCR, the New California Republic which is a faction that works with laws and such as they did before the bombs fell, and Caesers Legion, a faction based upon the old Romian Empire which is build upon slaves.  There are two major differences in the two games. Fallout 3 is build upon the idea that you are fresh out of the vault. In the game, everything is new to you ánd your character. Fallout: New Vegas is not really build upon this idea. You were shot in the head and you start your journey from a little farmers town.  Fallout 3 has an interesting storyline which I really enjoyed. It feels more personal then in New Vegas. Fallout: New Vegas has a lot (and I mean a lot) of choices. The game is bigger than Fallout 3, because it has more quests.  I chose New Vegas because I wanted to have a lot of things to do in the game. But I now regret this decission. I think you should buy Fallout 3 first, it's a great beginning for Fallout games in general if you have never played one. You get all the basics early on in the game and your goal is pretty clear. If you already played Fallout 4, then I'd recommend you to buy Fallout: New Vegas.

Fallout: New Vegas is the continuation of the series of Fallout games from Bethesda. Using similar controls, mechanics, and a similar engine from the previous instalment makes jumping into this title very easy but there are some significant and pretty fun differences.  Skills have been updated first and foremost. Small Guns and Big Guns have been merged into Guns while there's a new skill Survival which allows you to cook and create poisons. Equally Explosives now covers not only the grenades and mines in the game but any weapon which fires an explosive shell. This makes an interesting variant for some characters who would have been in a very niche market using Explosives back in Fallout 3.  There's also Hardcore mode. It awards an achievement, requires you to sleep (and eat and drink), makes it so that crippled limbs can only be healed with a Doctor's Bag, Stimpaks and other healing items also heal over time rather than instantly, and can be quite an interesting gameplay experience.  Damage Threshold is making a return from the previous instalments and is probably the biggest change for early game characters. Unlike Damage Resistance, which negates a certain percentage of damage- Damage Threshold (DT) completely ignores it. This means that with heavier armour the bandits and ghouls won't be able to damage you at all but it also works in reverse. It creates an interesting gameplay experience where you are unable to tackle the strongest and toughest enemies immediately, often as the damage required to break their DT is only available on weapons at 75-100 skill with a particular weapon.  Other changes include the removal of Bobbleheads and the addition of Implants which are tied to your Endurance statistic, Gecko Kebabs, lots of different houses, Las Vegas (uh, New Vegas), cazadores, a nomadic culturally stunted group of ordinance loving Vault dwellers, a number of bandit clans, cazadores, Joshua Graham, and a dozen different endings.  The DLC is a mixed bag (personally). I love the nostalgic and sci-fi humour of Old World Blues, I enjoy the story behind Honest Hearts, and find the Lonesome Road to be a thoroughly enjoyable trawl through your back story. However, Dead Money is not a favourite of mine. There's nothing fun about being taken, naked, with a collar on you, to a strange place while an old man watches you fight crazy guys in gas masks, with nothing more than a spear (when you're a Guns character). Unless you're into that sort of thing.  However, on the whole, I find that Fallout: New Vegas is a very enjoyable experience. It's got the kind of choices, plot development, and freedom that you can pretty much do whatever you like wherever you want to bar the few main quests that are necessary to your chosen end. The addition of Factions has made the gameplay experience more realistic and allowed for many more conclusions to the quests than you could have previous. Long gone are the days of mystical Karma where that guy you shot in Megaton is making you hated in Rivet City. Now that guy you shot in Goodsprings has no effect on the people of The Strip.  There are a lot more opportunities to develop and build your character in a number of ways. You can create a completely diplomatic character using Speech and Barter checks to get through fights rather than guns, or you can create an all out war machine with every kind of weapon known to man, or you could even create a character that thematically fits the idea of a cowboy or ol' Western hero. It's up to you. Unlike Fallout 3 where there were certain skills needed to pass through some quests without hassle or combat was the major option- it isn't the same here.  Equally if you're feeling like you want a bit more from the game you can always crack open Hardcore mode. It doesn't seem like much of a difference until you realise how many enemies in the game cripple you, how often you can realistically stop to eat/drink, and how much you value the instant healing of Stimpaks. You'll get into the habit of preventive healing rather than adaptive healing. It's a great little twist on an already immersive game.  Which is my final point and something that I feel both Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas do so very well- immersion. Sure, there's still a HUD (which would be difficult to remove) but there's a lot of other great things as well. The atmosphere, the NPCs, the corny Western references, the music on the radio, the music of the game in general, the feeling of setting out across this unusual and hostile wasteland, the diversity of locations in the DLC, the great number of changes the world has when you do certain things or befriend certain people. It's a game that feels alive and has a lot of promise for the future of the series.

When I first played New Vegas, my reaction was fairly lukewarm. I got the game when it was released back in 2010 for PS3. I was a 16-year-old kid who didn’t care about the story, nor could I really wrap my head around all of the political themes that pervade this game. I just wanted it to be more Fallout 3 where I ran around and made heads explode in V.A.T.S. In this regard, I was disappointed. The game’s story is much deeper than what is offered in Fallout 3. I got the Ultimate Edition 2 years ago during the summer sale because I never played the DLC and got it for ~$7. Since then it has become one of my most played games on Steam and one of my favorite games of all time, so I figured I should write a review and explain why I love this game so much.  New Vegas’s greatest strength is its understanding of player choice. Obsidian made an effort to make sure that you actually have multiple choices in most (if not all) scenarios. When most games think of choice, they think you have the freedom to be either the second coming of Christ, or Satan incarnate. They take a binary approach with no middle ground. I’m sorry for opening up this old flame war, but I would use Bethesda’s quest design as an example of the binary choice I’m talking about. Fallout 3 gave you the option of either being a goody-two-shoes, or a horrible monster who is the scourge of the wasteland. In New Vegas, you can tackle every situation in multiple ways depending on how you want to play the game. Maybe you can talk your way out with the speech skill, or pass a sneak check to avoid combat. Your skills and the character you decide to play truly matter in this game. The game is less focused on the karma system of Fallout 3, and, as a result, is not as limited. There is no one right answer to many of the problems in this game.  The gameplay and combat are adequate, but, admittedly, could be much better. It has shooting system that is standard for most games nowadays, where you can shoot from the hip or aim down the sights if you wish to be more accurate. It does a decent enough job, but it does not compare to other games with a more combat-heavy focus. Guns have almost no recoil and are laser accurate, which can get boring if you use automatics. Melee and unarmed are extremely viable and are probably my favorite way to play the vanilla game. They give the game a more Skyrim/Oblivion-type feel. You’ll have fun no matter what type of weaponry you choose to specialize in, but the gunplay does feel clunky at times.  The biggest problem with this game is that it can crash a lot. My crashes did not seem as frequent as some of the others that I have read about, but I still would save very often. The game has some goofy glitches too that can occasionally screw up quests too (thankfully, since this is the PC edition, you can fix broken quests with console commands). The technical issues come because the game was developed in only 18 months, reusing most of the assets from Fallout 3. That’s not an excuse, but it gives you an idea of some of the problems in this game.    Overall, there is tons of content in this game. My first PC playthrough clocked in around 70 hours, and that was even when I knew where I was going. It’s definitely worth the money, and still holds up today. If you haven’t already, buy it and see what all the hype is about.  5/5 --------------------------------------------  I also want to talk about mods, but didn’t want to let it impact my review. The mods in this game take what is already a great game and make it damn near perfect. As I mentioned before, the fundamentals of this game are solid, and mods expand on that. Additionally There are so many great ones out there, and people are still modding it today. Most of my playtime is probably from just going through the countless mods that are out there and seeing what is offered. They can fix some of the problems in this game, and end seemingly endless amounts of new content. If you play this game and don’t mod it, you’re missing out on the best part.  ***I must also mention that many people who buy this game lately are experiencing issues with crashing. This is due to a Windows update that broke something. If you roll back your video card’s drivers to the ones offered in July (368.81 for Nvidia users), everything should work fine.

Oh my gosh, I love Fallout...3! When I first got it at the blockbuster at the age of 14, I was like 'What the hell is this? Some sort of...first person...zombie...bandit shooter?' Then, when I began the game and was pushed through my black mom's thighs, my mouth was agape! I spend hundreds of hours in Fallout 3, just investigating and exploring and shooting and doing bad and good and all kinds of things! In fact, it's one of the few bethesda games I completed the main missions AND side quests (Except for that Rad Scorpion Cave thing...Screw that thing).  I was ready for Fallout New Vegas, I was just...so ready to love it! Then it came out. And I liked it. Okay, You are a courier in the mojave who get's their head blown in, and instead of running away from the guy who shot you in the head, you recover and go on a quest to complete your delivery, one way or the other. In the meantime, every single faction in the mojave looks to you and says,' HEY, JOIN US AND WE CAN GIVE YOU MONEY/WEAPONS/HUGS/WOMEN/MEN/GAMBLING/ARMOR/CLOTHES/A COIN WITH YOUR FACE ON IT.' Because...you are...a very talented courier who somehow got more powerful when you were shot in the head? I dunno, I just think being in a vault with your father being liam Neeson is a much more believable reason why people want you.  The good thing about Fallout New Vegas is that despite it's desert setting, it is a very interesting and complex enviroment to explore in. You can find little stories in how these happen, or why this or how that happened, and most of them are subtle and often just say 'It's the mojave, baby.'. I dig that alot in games. The characters are alot funnier and it gives off a more 'see what happens' kind of deal than FallOut 3, where you failing means the death of the Eastern Coast while what you do in Fallout New Vegas is almost petty and rather more about keeping the peace or creating chaos for you to profit from. It makes the factions system a lot more refreshing and a better fit then if they just went for another Washington DC thing. But the bad news? The game...is just long. I swear to god, I have created at least 10 characters in this game and only once did I get to the ending with them. The hoops you had to go through the actually do ANY of the endings just makes me cringe in how difficult is was. Often the game actually BREAKS during missons that have you do something due to Bethesda having some sort of hattred of players actually completing their games. They want you to EXPLORE, WHY STOP DOING THAT, MAN!? And sometimes a character just doesn't work, like the man who shoots you in the head is just boring and that plot thread doesn't do much, The guy who runs New Vegas is just kinda meh (The robots he commands are another thing, as they are just so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cool and funny. I mean, the cowboy dude should have been the one who actually ran things!) And the guy who runs New Vegas seems awfully similar to the big bad of Fallout 3. I mean, think about it! Just...think about it, okay?  DO I RECOMMEND THIS GAME: YES  While it is not as big of a thrill for me as Fallout 3, this game strives towards a new thing and does it well. The characters and setting are often fun, and the quests and general feel of the game is lighthearted and much more rewarding in many ways than to Fallout 3. Just don't expect to finish the main quest, as the ending is far too long and convulted.  SUGGESTIONS(FOR GAME DEVS): Go back to California and focus on a more civilized Fallout where you are a major leader in a community that slowly changes shape and becomes either a totalitarian paradise or a flawed democracy. Just saying.

I wasn't sure about Fallout New Vegas when I saw it was developed by Obsidian. This is the same company of former Bioware developers who almost destroyed the Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic series with a subpar sequel. Obsidian claimed a lot of the problems with that game were because they had to rush it in time for Xmas and maybe they were telling the truth because I have to admit, Fallout New Vegas is a much better product than Fallout 3. A real pleasant surprise!   I enjoyed my first few days with Fallout 3, but it became boring very quickly. It almost reminded me of Oblivion. I enjoyed Morrowind, and I really enjoyed Skyrim, but I have yet to complete Oblivion because it bored me to tears. Fallout 3 had many of the same problems. Generic side quests, bleh weapons, boring landscapes.... Polished games for sure, but just a litle too generic in design to feel as alive as Fallout New Vegas or Skyrim, if that make sense.   Fallout 3 did have some cool offerings, but New Vegas really took the new Fallout engine by Betheseda to a whole new level. Crafting, better side quests, factions... and what I love most, the game doesn't feel scaled to your level as much as Fallout 3, and especially Oblivion did. If you go north where you first begin the game, you will die... quickly! If you go east, same thing. I love RPGs that don't try and scale the bad guys to your level and make you pay for exploring. I also enjoy New Vegas's hardcore option that makes it that much more challenging because both Fallout 3 and New Vegas are too easy on the standard mode. I know Fallout 3 has mods that offer hardcore, but I'm giving Fallout New Vegas credit for having it from the start. It's almost like Obsidian took a look at popular complaints and suggestions from Fallout 3 and did their best to add it to Fallout New Vegas. I played through this game at least twice before I took the plunge on user made modulars. And the mods for this game are VERY impressive! I recommend you check out Nexus Mods for a thorough collection, but be forewarned, you will have to do some heavy research online to make sure it all works right. There are some terrific sets of videos on YouTube developed by a British chap who will walk you through all the many utilities and popular mods for both Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas, if you're willing to spend the hours. There are certain mod installers, and even fixer-up utilities that are necessary if you're going to get the most impresive mods.   I can't say enough about this game. It really brought me back to Fallout after a 'meh experience' from Fallout 3, and has me eagerly looking forward to the sequel. I bought the Ultimate Edition on sale for about $4 on Steam's Summer Sale and it's one of the best bang for my buck games I've played in a while. Most of the DLC is pretty goood, with only one that I thought was straight up boring, but I'll let you decide and I would recommend you get all DLC as well as the best user rated mods at Nexus, since this game is not as supported on Steam's workshop as some other titles.

This isn’t a fault of the game or the story telling, just that Obsidian (again) pushed the envelope too hard. And in game development that is no bad thing at all.  At over 550 hours played at the time of writing this, New Vegas is easily up there as one of the great games I’ve played of all time, and I don’t exaggerate. At the time of this review, I've recorded 35 hours, 8 achievements and completed several quests. But this review isn't really meant for the seasoned vets or gamers who already play the game and have gone through the gauntlet of problems Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas are known for. No, this review is for the gamer who's on the fence about purchasing this game or are just beginning and have succumbed to the crashes, freezes, and only god knows what else.   To be blunt, this game sucked right out the gate. CTDs were killing me, much like Fallout 3 did when I was playing it. But after going through the community forums, mods, YouTube videos and the like, I've pasted together bits-n-pieces to turn this game into a stable treasure. As god is my witness, I haven't had a crash since diligently repatching this game under the advisement of others. NONE. ZERO! Not only that, but there are no microstutters, freezes, pauses or glitches of any kind. The frame rate is remarkably stable at 60 fps although only 30 fps is really needed.   If I were given a scale from 1 to 10 to judge this game on 'pre-community' patches, I would give it a 4. The game in itself at launch is good but buggy and wrecked. It's as if it wasn't finished upon release. But i'm still a sucker for open-world gaming.   If I were given a scale from 1 to 10 to judge this game on 'post-community' patches, I would give it a 9. Yes, it's THAT good. The graphics (textures) are much better. The speed of the game is smooth and stable. The story flows along wihtout interfering with your personal playstyle. This is the way the game is meant to be played. The ONLY reason I took a point off is because of some bugs in the programming referring to quest. But to be honest, that's expected in a game of this sort. You'll come across that from time to time but is doesn't break the game or quest for that matter.   In closing, this is a gem, especially at this time when the game is offered at twenty bucks or less during steam sales. As I stated, I've played for 35 hours at the time of this review and can't wait to get back at it, but I haven't even REACHED New Vegas yet! I'm laughing as I type it. There is so much stuff going on...I can't even get to where I'm going without getting side-tracked by some wonderful missions. The characters are great too. Fallout: New Vegas is not a direct sequel but uses the same engine and style as Fallout 3. While New Vegas was created by Obsidian, Fallout 3 was created by Bethesda. New Vegas is often considered the superior game, due to it's tighter pacing and more interesting world and characters. Fallout 3 has more exploration and a bigger map though.  In the game you play as a mysterious courier who wakes up buried alive in a small town in the middle of the desert. All you remember is that you have to deliver a coin to the city of New Vegas and then the usual Fallout madness begins. The journey to New Vegas is filled with peril and several new factions are introduced along the way together with familiar ones like the Brotherhood of Steel.  What sets New Vegas apart from any other Fallout city is that it was reasonably undamaged when the bombs dropped and the city even still has electricity. When you do get to New Vegas, things get even messier as everything is not all it appears to be...  DLC  Dead Money. You play as a captive along with others at a casino and you must uncover it's legendary treasure Honest Hearts. Discover the true nature of the legendary Burned Man as you work with and fight primitive tribes. Lonesome Road. This takes the entire game full circle as you explore the canyons of the Divide Old World Blues. You become a lab rat in a maze of pre-war technology. Advice  The only true must-have is Old World Blues. It is absolutely fantastic. The rest are kind of hit and miss. Pick up the ultimate edition with all the DLC included if you find it on a sale though, as it is usually a deep discount. It was available for $4.99 during the Steam Summer Sale of 2013

FO:NV continues to be one of my go to games. If you're familiar with FO3, you'll find more of the same formula here, but set in Vegas. There's no shortage of quests, interesting characters, equipment, and generally awesome exploration to be had. I honestly couldn't say how long the main story line is, but there's a pretty incredible amount of content to explore (and that's just in the game itself, let alone mods and such).  If you're looking for a good post-apocalyptic, open world, action/adventure with passable character development, FO:NV should definitely be at the top of your list.

Overall the game is significantly buggy, more so than it's predecessor despite many people claiming otherwise. It also lacks the same depth and personality the previous title had, and I found many instances of a poor, poooooorly written script, many characters will say one thing, do another, or say the exact opposite of what they just said. Unlike Fallout 3 your skill checks are Hard set, so if you aren't the level required by the time you run across the many, MANY one time chance skill checks you always fail, whereas fallout 3 let you slide by with your level determining a % chance to succede. Like fallout 3 the terminal hacking and lockpicking are hard set as well, so even if you're level 74 you can't attempt a level 75 lock or terminal. The main game has three major paths you can take in the main story, and a whole plethora of hidden side quests you can fail at a moments notice. The DLC stories are much more entertaining on the whole, some of them can be a headache first time through but the rewards are notably worth it in most cases. The game's 'hardcore' mode is it's biggest shining feature, but it has a tendency to get in the way for an ammo hoarder as ammo has weight to it, albeit teensy, it adds up fast, I once had over 300 lbs that I lost in ammo alone. I certainly enjoyed it more than I expected, but I don't suggest this game without mods.

Basically, this is Fallout 3 if it's writers gave a damn about the lore, atmosphere of the original Fallouts. The result is an inspired and surprisingly disbelief-suspending setting that combines the Wild West with 1950s Las Vegas, whilst retaining Fallout's trademark post-nuclear world with mutants and raygun-gothic technology. The characters are far more memorable and the open world actually feels like a world - and not an artificial field of formulaic, neatly-organized POIs and busywork (ala Far Cry 3 or any modern Ubisoft game, for that matter.)  If you haven't played a Fallout game before - I wouldn't worry. Just dive in. The plot is self-contained and familiarity with lore from the previous games isn't really necessary, though it adds to the enjoyment of certain characters and quests.  Be warned however, that as this is an Obsidian game (built on an engine from Bethesda, no less) there are glitches, bugs and rough patches - though the game is hardly unplayable, and there's still tons of great mods that further polish this gem.   The DLC is also really good.

A brilliant follow-up to Fallout 3. Obsidian's signature impressive writing is quite noticeable here, especially when it comes to the half-dozen companions you meet, each of whom are wonderfully characterized with loads of dialogue and several quests related to them. Survival and an expanded crafting system go a long way towards making you feel like a badass just for living through another day in the wasteland, and the fact that each faction tracks your actions leads to much more interesting moral choices.  Really the only downside I can think of is that a lot of the new content feels visually out of place. Many of Obsidian's models are oddly low-detail and poorly rendered, and several of the new items are just facsimiles of real-world weapons and equipment, maintaining none of the previous games' retrofuturistic, alternate universe feel.   Overall though, the game is a massive improvement over its predecessors ( yes, all of them). Definitely worth it for any CRPG fan.

He crept up the hill slowly, his duster jacket flapping in the Mojave winds. It was midday, but he had chosen to approach the run-down prison from the hill with the sun to his back, a tactical move. There would be no glare from the sun to betray his position and his trusted sniper rifle, and he had to make use of all of these things if he was going to come out of this alive, and paid. He had taken on a job to wipe out the inhabitants of the prison from the local pushover authorities, the N.C.R. In his opinion everyone out here in this god-forsaken place deserved a bullet between the eyes, but then who would be left to buy all the crap he acquired off the corpses of those stupid enough to either get in his way or become his target? Nah, better to pick the side with money and a possible means to get out of this hell hole, and wipe out the rest. As he reached the crest of the hill and looked down into the prison yard, he began to pick out many of his targets, gauging their threat level between who was closer, who had the bigger guns, and who was seperated and could be picked off quietly. 3 of the guard towers still stood, and the convicts who had taken over had made good use of these, pilfering the rifles within each and establishing their own watch. They would have to go first, being that they had the best line of sight to spot him, glare or none. He then turns on his V.A.T.S., allowing him to pick and choose his targets and their appendages. He has just enough V.A.T.S. points to kill all 3 watchmen, but only if he goes for clear headshots. The nearest two ping in around 85% successful hit chance, good odds for any wastelander, but the third being the farthest pings in around 46%.....A number he doesnt like. However the sun is just cresting over him in the sky, and within a few minutes he will have lost his celestial ally and gained a new enemy. He tells himself, now or never, lines up his shots, and engages his V.A.T.S. calculations. With lightning-quick reflexes, he fires his first shot, and quickly moves to the second target, having to trust in his aim to hit the first. Once the second bullet leaves the chamber, his sights quickly flash to the third target. He fires that last round, and watches it spiral its way towards the tower. Almost as if time itself decides to hold its breathe in anticipation of this moment, everything slows on the third round. It spins lazily over the courtyard, intent on the tower and its one sentient form. The watchman takes a drag off an old dirty cigarette he traded for from one of the other inmates, one last, long sweet drag, as his eyes suddenly spend a fraction of a second seeing his two fellows in the other towers going down, and his ears hearing 3 shots. His eyes widen, just a fraction, in dread knowing where that 3rd shot was meant to go. The bullet pierces his skull, straight into his cranium, ricocheting inside his head until it explodes with force out the back, causing his head to explode outwards. The wastelander watches with satisfaction, now happy that he had chosen that Lady Luck perk, because she was surely watching over him today with that shot. However, he then hears a growl from behind, turns around quickly and immediately dismisses any notion of Lady Luck giving a rats ♥♥♥ about him. Standing before him is a Deathclaw, one ugly reptilean son of a ♥♥♥♥♥, standing 8 ft tall, with burning eyes staring right at him. Swearing loudly, he switches to his plasma gun which is falling apart and seen better days. His V.A.T.S. at the moment are depleted, so this will have to be all skill. Just before he charges in, he thinks to himself '♥♥♥♥ this deathclaw, ♥♥♥♥ this prison, ♥♥♥♥ the N.C.R., and ♥♥♥♥ this whole desert'. 10 out of 10. Buy it now or Grandma will call you and say she hates you.

I enjoy Fallout for the dystopian post-apocalyptic vibes, but I really enjoy New Vegas because it is made after the original two Fallout games. The reason I skip over console versions of most rpgs either made or produced by Bethesda is for the modding potential.  The stand-alone game, Fallout New Vegas, is very fun to play with many base weapons to choose from and factions to join. There are countless ways to replay this game over and over, and that possibility becomes almost infinite thanks to the modding community.  Yes, the game is full of glitches in the beginning when you purchase the vanilla game. But you can download many community patches that fix an untold amount of issues. Don't like that you heard there is cut content? Several modders are developing patches that will bring back cut content such as quests, weapons, and characters.  I feel especially that some of the factions feel meaningless, such as Caesar's Legion. It was rumored that faction had almost equal quests and depth as the NCR and offered many followers. But this was one of the largest cuts to NV that I saw an issue with, as Obsidian ran out of time and villified the Legion so no player would see how lackluster they were. There are mods that fix that, too, and others on the way still.

The Fallout series is easily one of my favorite franchises in the RPG genre. Similar to Skyrim, you have a large open world with quests abound, and its highly moddable to customize to your own tastes. While the Vanilla game itself is above average, mods take it to another level. No need to worry about things getting complicated though, since the Nexus Mod Manager and similar tools make it very easy.   Thematically it's a mashup of 1940s-1950s Sci-Fi meets post-apocalyptic, with just a dash of Western. I admit Fallout 3 has a better environment since you're exploring the bombed-out ruins of Washington DC versus the open Mojave desert, but the mechanics are improved and the game itself is optimized for modern operating systems. Fallout 3 on the other hand will put up a fight if you're running Windows 7 or 8.  In the end, I'd say New Vegas is a solid RPG, it just needs a few mods to have it reach its full potential. Definitely worth your time and money, especially on sale.

Please read the full review or don't read it at all:  So in light of the new Fallout 4 hype I finally bought this game after having a bad experience a few years back with Fallout 3 (game wouldn't open past the starting menu, yes, I tried ALL the online fixes), but back on subject to New Vegas.  This game is an outstanding experience except for it's notoriously horrendous performance issues (crashes, freezes, etc.) and just general bugs. I love this game, and would recommend it, I would also recommend getting the 99 cent 'Courier's Stash' DLC, the armor, weapons, and stimpaks help tremendously. I would not however recommend expecting a smooth experience. You must be willing to deal with constantly being interrupted for stuttering, freezing, and crashing at random and quite frustrating times (namely when you haven't saved in a while.) That being said, once again, this is an amazing game, with loads of quests and places to explore, things to fight, people to interact with, and even drugs to become addicted to, you will never be bored in the Mojave.  Want to relax, maybe have a drink? Plenty of bars and lounges for that. Want to gamble your savings away? New Vegas has some great casinos too. Or maybe you want to just kill stuff? Well there's certainly no shortage of that. All in all: 8/10, save frequently, have patience, and enjoy.

I found this game after playing Morrowind, Fallout 4, and Skyrim fairly thoroughly. The last two have better graphics (go figure) but FONV has a much more complex storyline. The interfaces on FO4 and Skyrim are superior, as are their leveling and perk concepts, and although FONV has as many questlines as the other games, they are often more complex. I have found it impossible to choose an optimal path through the maze of interconnected stories and choices (made even worse by a variety of skill requirements that affect the choices available). In some cases my feeling was not one of accomplishment, but of exhaustion and relief that it was finally over and I had a good excuse to work a different quest or even play some other game. The quests seem far more manageable once the main quest is over and after 200 hours I can't say that the game isn't engaging. It is. I recommend keeping a wiki open for guidance; I certainly needed it frequently.

Created by the disestablished successor of creator of the original Fallout games, Fallout New Vegas is not a direct sequel of Fallout 3 but does use same Gamebryo Engine as Fallout 3 making it difficult not to compare the two games.  The game takes place in the post apocalyptic Mohave Desert near the New Vegas Strip. You start as a courier who's had the misfortune of getting your package stolen, in the process, you end up shot in the head, buried, and left for dead, however you wake up rescued and now you want answers. Two factions are vying for power, Caesars Legion and the New California Republic, other smaller tribes and factions are not to be discounted of course. How you deal with all these different groups is your choice.  Pros: Open World Design Dozens of minor quests Fun Mini Games Great Character Progression and Customization Weapon Customization System Improved Companion System (Bonus Points for getting real life famous entertainer Mr. Las Vegas AKA Wayne Newton to play Radio host Mr. New Vegas) Awesome Modding Community for PC users keeping the game alive  Cons: Lack luster plot (even main quest and dlc in my opinion) Poor Optimization for windows 7 and up Only truly open world at later levels due to 'walls' of high level enemies blocking many areas off. Short main story quest line  Now while it is difficult not to compare it to the admittedly superior Fallout 3 (in my opinion). Overall, New Vegas is a truly fun experience that truly holds its own in the Fallout franchise. It's a great game that can keep any RPG fan easily occupied for hours to come.

Warning: Review does contain New Vegas storyline spoilers! Side Note: This is a review in progress I am planning to edit this in the future.  Well, Fallout New Vegas. Bottom line is, this game is a masterpiece. I know that the quality control of Bethesda dropped when they gave obsidian the role of coding New Vegas and there are a lot more graphical problems and some game breaking glitches. But whether you like a game or not you must look past a games faults. I passonately play the fallout franchise. I clocked this game 4 times on xbox 360, once on hardcore. I couldn't stop. I love getting lost in a role playing character whether I take on the persona of a caring wasteland dweller, helping the civilisations inhabitants or a physcotic manic with no respect for anyone. This is what makes me love fallout so much. Not only is the story for both games amazing but the setting is even better. Something about post-apocolyptic senarios just get me like no other setting does. Now I will admit, the combat and features in New Vegas are a huge step up from Fallout 3. Even the ability to have full iron sights is a huge improvement, but a even further extention to the crafting system and new weapon modifications mean that there is a lot more to do in NV than 3. To be perfectly honest if you want to play a falloput game for a story, pick 3 over NV any day. NV story is a bit short and the final battle at Hoover Dam, no matter who you side with, once you have completed the finale, you will be sent back to your last save before the battle which in my personal opinion is dumb. I would have loved to continue on after the cut scene narrator has finished explaining what actions you took affected the wasteland. If you side with Caesar's Legion, the narrator will explain how the legion took over the strip and practically wiped out the NCR from Vegas, so it would have been great to roam the fully Legion controlled Vegas.  All in all if you want more from what you got from Fallout 3, purchase this game and its dlc's you will not be disappointed!

Fallout New Vegas... Starting the great intro that pulled you into this post-apocolyptic area within minutes, i had already began to love the game.   There was a few issues at first... Mainly focused around the feeling of boredom in Goodsprings, that I still feel today. However past that point of getting used to the game and out of Goodsprings I love it.  It was a brilliant year for game-play, in 2012, and Fallout New Vegas sat as one of the highest quality games in terms of RPG, at least for me. I loved nearly every bit of it. I fell in love with that 50's feel mostly, with the music just capturing me completely. But the humour behind it, the funky features, unique range of weapons, completely customizable set up and huge world made my love for it an addiction. I even enjoyed the DLCs that gave a nice break to the Mojave scenery.  There was a few bugs and glitches, but not when I have swapped over to PC from Console and covered every inch of the game with mods, it runs like a beautiful well loved & oiled machine.  It needs these mods, trust me as the graphics don't meet that expected of 2015, but over-all it's still my favourite game of all time, and my reason for love of retro 50's stuff & MMO's.  My only wish is that more games these days offered this high quality. Bring on Fallout 4!

F:NV is yet another first-person RPG from Bethesda, with all their trademark goodness. You play a courier hired by the Mojave Express to deliver a package to New Vegas. Unfortunately, you're waylaid on your way there, the package is stolen, the thieves shoot you in the head and leave you to die in a shallow grave. Luckily, you're rescued, and you set out to recover the package and get vengence.  Along the way you'll meet all sorts of characters; unsavory escaped convicts, mysterious robots, helpful ghouls, and more! You'll also become embroiled in the conflict between the two super-powers of the area; the more-or-less democratic New California Republic, or the ruthless, slaver forces of the Legion.  It's up to you on how you'll fit in amongst the irradiated denizens of the Mojave. Just make sure you have water, bullets, and maybe a companion or two before you wander the Wasteland...

The vanilla game shows the vast potential of this series, however to truly unlock the full experience mods will be required. Alot of mods!  In preparation for the soon-to-be-released 5th jount into the Fallout universe, I have decided to revisit the games that got me hooked in the first place. Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas. To that purpose I will be using one of the more ingenious mods created, namely A Tale of Two Wastelands (TTW).  It took a solid 3 days of modding to ensure the consistent function of nearly 200 diverse mods, but it has truly been worth the effort.

Playing with Mods are fun, compared to attempting to play this on console. The reason I say attempting, is the console versions tend to freeze & lock up after a couple of hours of gameplay. On PC however the game runs much more smoothly & if your system can handle it, I would highly recommend getting the 4GB memory mod from Nexus Mods, as it will allow up to 4GB of your RAM to be dedicated to Fallout NV while playing, making the game run that much more smoothly.  My only real complaint with NV is, I played it for the first time about 9 months after beating Fallout 4 multiple times, & I would honestly recommend playing it BEFORE Fallout 4 if you can, otherwise the power armor is going to seem quite.... underwhelming in comparison.  In NV the graphics for it are lackluster & it literally looks like a poorly skinned set of football pads, compared to an suit that you have you unlock & climb into (like in Fallout 4). Otherwise, I found New Vegas to be much more challenging even on the lesser difficulties than Fallout 4 ever was, as I always attempt to play through the game the first several times without mods, & replay it on each difficulty setting, for each different faction ending, before I feel comfortable using Mods or console commands (which is essentially cheating).  After owning this on both PS3 & PC, I would highly recommend the PC version over getting it for PS3 / X360. Even on a mid range graphics card like a single GTX 960, it's considerably more crisp & 'pretty' as far as graphics & gameplay go.  I'm still debating getting the PC version of Fallout 3 GOTY. I remember on consoles it seeming very brown & dark pretty much everywhere, I'm not sure how much of a difference PC will make, but most people in the forums already say you're better off just getting New Vegas & 4 (if your system will run it).  I honestly found that New Vegas was much more challenging even on lower difficulty settings than Fallout 4 was on considerably higher difficulties. Some people may or may not like that. Personally I love / hate it, lol. It definitely adds a level of realism to the game that more hardcore gamers will appreciate.

I like that all the companions can be collected into a weird family of sorts. Though it's a desert, at least the area given makes sense for the amount of decay and dead color schemes.  The only real qualm I have with this game is the inital customization, which has been kind of terrifying and weird during this era of their game engine. Plus all of the endings are kind of depressing? Keeps me motivated to not end the game since there isn't an after-game section.

I realize this review is coming late to the party but as this is the first chance I've had to play Fallout NV it's hopefully better late than never.  Having played every incursion of Fallout stemming back to the original game I'm somewhat of a loyalist to the series, especially so to the first two. In my opinion FO NV is the first 'modern times' instalment of the game that does the the original two justice. It is quite simply a masterpiece of gaming excellence, well-crafted, well-written, well-voiced, with highly interesting and very imaginitive storylines, histories, back-stories, the humor, the horrors, etc.   We're never going to have the same 'feel' or 'moodiness' as the originals had, but perhaps it's better that those originals stay just that... original. I very much like the mood and feel of NV too.   On the technical side, for those of you who are now on Windows 10 (like me) I can tell you that the game plays quite well. I'm running it on the absolute most ultra-high settings and I'm experiencing few crashes. It does crash, but so too does virtually every game I've ever played. As for glitches, seeing as it's an older game most if not all of the known bugs are well-documented online along with any fixes or work-arounds.  My recommendation for what it's worth:   As I said NV is now an older game, and thus sold at a discounted price, and comes with the entire DLC package (set of 4), and I've found it to be so worth the money. Getting and playing the four add-ons is a must. If I were to rate it out of 10 I'd give it at least a 9, perhaps 9.5.  Happy gaming.

originally published September 13th 2011  Fallout:New Vegas is a slow burn but not in an awesome roast-a-pig-in-a-backyard-firepit kind of way, more a boil-a-frog kind of way. So much time is invested that by the time it's over a beaten down Stockholm Syndrome sets in, goading the player to make it to the pay-off to justify the time investment.   As The Courier (when you are actually one of many couriers) you start the game in a grave, a bullet lodged in your skull. Rescued by a overly friendly robot (that conveniently shows up all over the place), The Courier is mended by a small-town doctor and set out into the world with a single quest-find the man that betrayed him/her.  Like Fallout 3 (and on the same engine) F:NV drops the player into an open world from the beginning, but firmly guides through quests and rewards. As an action RPG, leveling deeply affects the ability to travel from environment to environment as various flora and fauna as well as enemies are placed to deter much off-the-beaten-path travel.  This wide-but-still-a-corridor approach pushes the player into a variety of environments suitable to their level and as diverse as an abandoned town,a Vault, an abandoned farm, a ruined town filled with survivors (good/bad/one with the gun) and Vegas. This also serves to level and equip the player enough to surive the end-game with in New Vegas itself and where the meat of the story really is.   What began as a simple revenge tale ramps up in the last 10 hours to a tale of political power and intrigue as the Courier is given leave to aid or destroy various factions in the world. These choices determine the future of New Vegas itself and the surrounding lands. The meandering journey around the city informs these choices but for me, there was only one clear path, as none of the factions are particularily interesting or endearing.  Presented as an attempt to empathize with the plight of various peoples, F:NV is such a slog that the endless dialogue trees and barely animated charaters blur into one another, including the player companions. I encountered all of them, and while I saw the benefit each might bring as one of the two allowed, I found none to be very interesting. I ended up keeping a robot and a dog for most of my travels.  Only in that last part of the game does the momentum build, including a truly shocking (and entirely optional moment) involving would-be dictator Mr. House. Only then does the game find its legs and move the story forward, barrelling towards a deliciously violent conclusion.  Obstensibly a first-person shooter, I spent most of my gameplay time in 3rd person mode unless I was in combat. Once engaged with enemies, I immediately made use of the VATS targeting system, highlighting specific body parts to damage. Less a shooter than a dice-rolling RPG, F:NV relies entirely on stats to effect damage rather than player skill. Scoring critical hits in VATS never fails to be viscerally fulfilling as an enemy explodes into gore.  This game is very very brown   Visually a brown and yellow color scheme matches the locale of the nevada desert but it also undermines the previously established and far more striking look of Fallout 3. By using muted earth tones, the game just looks like mud, until New Vegas is reached, at which point it looks like neon-colored mud.  It is also replete with glitches, even this late into release and after multiple patches. Usually spawn or clipping issues, I never experienced anything game breaking, but it was hilarious to disarm an enemy, then have him run himself into a corner and up into the sky.  Like Bioshock 2, Fallout:New Vegas takes a long time to get cooking and engage the player. Unlike Bioshock 2, the visuals are not a hook to keep the player involved until the story ramps up. For those that relish exploration and discovery, New Vegas has some delightfully oddball areas that are quirky enough to keep one engaged, but those seeking narrative have a long road ahead.

Before anything else, a personal rant: This should have been Fallout 3, and Fallout 3 should have been, idk, Fallout: Capital Wasteland, to put mildly? Don't even get me started about what I think Fallout 4 should have been...  With that out of the way, allow me to say this: I'm not a huge fan of RPGs. In fact, I used to hate RPGs, but all this changed when I decided to immerse myself into the lore of the Fallout universe, after reading about it online. What got me a bit into the world of RPGs was Fallout 1 and 2, and subsequently, 3 and NV (Mass Effect as well, I guess, but that's outta the question...). The fact is, I tried a few other RPGs from time to time since I started playing Fallout, but none of them got me as hooked as did Fallout: New Vegas. I have, at the moment I'm writing this review, 126.5 hours counted towards it, but all these hours were achieved on a single character, on a single storyline. There are countless more possible unique endings to this game than I guess I could have achieved with all the hours I have put in to all my Steam games put together.  Now, to the game itself, more exactly, to the story. As I suppose I made quite explicit in my previous paragraph, this game is huge. Like, really, it's very long (provided you decide to finish not only the main quest, but at least SOME side-quests, like I did. Trust me, the writing on those makes them worth your time). It appears to me that Obsidian, the company responsible for the development of this game, (which, mind you, had some of those involved in the development of Fallout 1 and 2) really took their time to make a clever and engaging storyline(s). You will see that in many points you will have to make decisions that could affect the entire Wasteland, as, to a certain degree, your actions do carry weight in this game.  For gameplay and character development, I fell that, for a game from 2010, its gameplay is still pretty good, although it is, at times, 'clunky'. I, for one, didn't enjoy fighting in real time, for example. For combat, VATS was my method of choice, but I'm sure there are many that beg to differ. It also introduced a (in my opinion) rudimentary crafting system that I barely used, but that certainly gives many different advantages to those that do. The game's character development is as awesome as is the story, and closely intertwines with the gameplay. The skill system, combined with many perks that can be given to your character, alongside a diverse range of equipments make for a virtually limitless number of possible character builds.  Finally (because I really wanna sleep, but at the same time wanna help you folks lol), the graphics. Look at the game's screenshots, that's all I have to say. Good night.  tl;dr:  PROS: -Story (3x) -Gameplay -Character development (2x)  CONS:  -Graphics
