First off, don't let my time with the game fool you. I previously, as abhorent as it may sound to PC elitsists, owned this game on the Xbox 360 and clocked in well over 1,000 hours across several save files. I've a bit less experience with a modded version of this game, but I played with most of the mods that you could with Tale of Two Wastelands, which I recommend.  I strongly recommend this game which, in a post FO4 world, is easily the strongest entry in the series, surpassing the original two games, Fallout 3, and even Fallout 4. The world feels much more alive, even if at times the environments can be sparser than Fallout 3 or 4, due to stronger writing and world building. The factions within it feel like they're reacting and coexisting within the world rather than remaining in their separate bubbles without any acknowledgement of the others, besides perhaps 'You see that huge scary ship in the sky? Crazy right' from the rare extra. I would also argue this is an excellent 'Jumping in' point for the series as it includes all of the standard factions as well as some unique ones, though the Brotherhood of Steel is a weaker player in this game than most of the other entries.  It manages to, in my opinion, balance RPG and FPS elements in a way that both Fallout 3 and 4 failed to succeed in, besides perhaps the clever addition of energy weapons ironsights that was included in Fallout 4. The difficulty feels rather balanced, as well, and lacks the rather ridiculous 'Poor a million bullets into a Deathclaw' sequence that Fallout 4 has right at the intended start of the game.  tl;dr  Pros:  Excellent worldbuilding  The peak example of writing in the series  Easily the best entry in the series, you'll never experience anything as good as playing this for the first time when it comes to this series  Unique characters and factions  Great gameplay  Cons:  It's a Bethesda/Obsidian game, it's still a bit buggy. Fallout New Vegas is the entire reason I ever got into pc gaming in the first place. I'd played through it about 3 or 4 times on the xbox 360, and never got tired of exploring the Mojave. After hearing about the vast modding community and seemingly endless gameplay potential, I decided I was going to do everything humanly possible to play modded New Vegas on PC. That dream was achieved on October 25th, 2013, when I bought a pc capable of running New Vegas at max settings. I modded this game until its engine buckled under the weight of everything I threw at it, and kept going. Every single experience is different, and incredible. I've charged through hordes of super mutants in my custom made base, firing a mini nuke mini gun, watching my armies of enclave soldiers charge into the expanding glow. I've flown a vertibird over the north end of freeside and new vegas, destroying roaming gangs of zombies that ravaged the landscape. I've taken a train ride to to the Capital wasteland bringing two amazing titles together, thanks to the ambitious community that loves this series more than I do. This game is buggy, it is abstract, it is chaotic, and it is a masterpiece. This is a title that I will come back to 20 years from now, even when the other mountains of titles that surpass it mechanically and graphically stand ready, because it has proved itself to be one of the most memorable and captivating games I have ever experienced. I hope that Obsidian will be given the opportunity to craft another gem in the fallout series, and hope that Bethesda will consider passing them the torch once again. 10/10 game, would spend another month in game.

Fallout: New Vegas is a Post-Nuclear Role Playing game.  It is less about fighting against the conditions of a harsh wasteland to survive after a nuclear war, and more about Humanity fighting against itself to rebuild society. It gives the player a lot of choices that ultimately affect the future of Western America.  You can play many different roles, including, but not limited to: - A middle-aged woman who makes love to the man who shot her in the head, then proceeds to help an army of Roman Legionnaires wearing sports gear take over the area. - A young man who helps a group of convicts take over a small town, and then proceeds to help the Republic that those convicts hate the most take over the area. - An absolutely psychotic maniac who kills and eats everyone he/she can and then gets a smiley robot to help him/her take over the area. - An young woman with mental problems who commits Mutant genocide, and then helps a shrivelled-up old man connected to a computer who gets robots to pleasure him take over the area. Mix and match.  Fallout: New Vegas is one of the best modern Western RPGs.  It just works.

There is no way to properly describe how much I love this game in a simple review. This Fallout game is the best of the modern Fallout games (Modern as in: Fallout 3 and Fallout 4) in my opinion. I'll try to keep this review short.  This game focuses heavily on role-playing, world building, and it makes sure that your choices truly impact the game as a whole. The majority of your choices if not all of your choices will have some impact on the game world. Your choices do matter and make a difference unlike other games that give the illusion of choice, this game actually gives you it and makes you live with the consequences. Even the downloadable content gives you choices to make as well as new areas, characters, items, and ethical ideas to think about even after you finish the game. This game also does a great job in avoiding a 'Good vs. Evil' story like Fallout 3, and it makes sure to put everyone in the grey area in which all factions have good sides and arguments for their actions as well as flaws that are major and minor. This is also a game in which years later I am still finding new areas, easter eggs, quests, interesting characters, and even new ways to play!  To simply put it, I highly recommend this game and all its downloadable content. The only way to truly understand the complexity of this game is to play it multiple times in different ways and make difference choices. Again, buy this game and make sure to give yourself a enough time to really get into it.

If you liked Fallout 3 you'll love New Vegas, it completely expands upon Fallout 3 in story and gameplay. I enjoyed Fallout 3 but what I loved about New Vegas is how it gives you more choices on what kind of person you wanna be as well as how you want to tackle a problem. You can be a mercenary, a good-two-shoes, a bumbling idiot, whatever you want to try and the best part you see the results of your choices play out either for good or bad. The companions in this game have gotten better, what I mean is they have a more detailed backstory as well as quests that decide their fate at the end and although sometimes their AI can be stupid at times, they have saved my hide multiple times. The companions also have a companion wheel to quickly give actions and change settings which was a good step from 3. The gunplay has gotten a bit better but nothing too different from 3. All in all Fallout New Vegas has a lot of heart in it and it really deserves to be played at least once, and like I said you can play anyway you want heck I convinced the final boss to call it quits and go home...and the sucker listened to me!

Fallout: New Vegas is the only game that I can think of that lets you kill off all but one character (besides the Gun Runners robot vendor and children (latter of which can be modded in)) and complete the main story.   Unlike the latest Bethesda title (which I still find highly enjoyable), FNV is an actual RPG game. With a level cap and thus a limit on perk/stat points, how you spend those points makes a big difference in terms of gameplay.  FNV features multiple major and minor factions, each with their own unique quest lines that can be tied into the main story line. With memorable NPCs and amusing dialogue, it does not feel like a chore to complete.  Modding is a large selling point for this game. Almost all aspects of the game can be tailored in some way by mods. If you can think of something to mod, chances are, there is already a mod for it. FNV has one of the largest modding communities of any game and because of that, there are thousands of mods to choose from. Some of them changes major parts of the game, while others changes minor details. Clothing/armor mods add variety and additional character customization. Weapon mods makes combat more interesting. Visual mods such as ENBs, better textures or enviromental mods makes the rather dated graphics more appealing. There are NPC mods, quest mods and mods that add new areas to name a few.  To me, Fallout: New Vegas is the best Fallout game to date. With high replayability, it is more than worth it's $10 asking price. $20 for the Ultimate edition (recommended), which adds additional items and three new maps with engaging stories. I stress this even more so when it's on sale, at which point, there isn't a reason not to try out the game unless you absolutely can not spare three to five dollars.

New Vegas fixes everything that made Fallout 3 bad. Adding tons of new factions all with great quests you can dig into. You can join every single one of them and most aren't black or white decisions, they're always grey areas and that's important. Only real black or white faction in the game is the NCR and the Legion and even those are great fun to participate in.  A brand new story will have you start out in a small town called Goodsprings and work your way up all the way to New Vegas with tons of twists and turns along the way. The story in NV respects the lore a lot more than 3 as well.  There's new weapon modifications that let you upgrade the already vast amount of weapons you can use including lots of rare and unique weapons along the way.  The modding community is alive, always creating great mods to keep this game alive for as long as possible.  Probably my favourite addition is how no enemies can't be killed. You can just straight up kill everyone if you wanted to.  The only thing holding Fallout New Vegas back is the bugs. Although the game breaking bugs were all patched out at release there's still lots of small annoying ones that will ruin your immersion and can mess you up on a lot of side quests. Combine that with constant crashing on certain people's systems and those can ruin a game for some people.  9/10, undoubtedly my favourite game in the series and probably my favourite RPG. Nothing can top this. The game would probably be a 10/10 if the bugs were fixed. I don't usually do scores and if I did I wouldn't give high ones like this often but I can't stress enough how much I love New Vegas and how if you haven't played it yet, you need to. Now. Obsidian sure as hell know how to make an RPG.

All about the Fallout

Fallout: New Vegas is, in my opinion, the definitive Fallout experience  For fans of the old isometric Fallout style, it's quirky and original dialogue and compelling storytelling as well as its freedom of choice and true RPG gameplay, this three dimensional edition of the classic series is as close as you'll get. Whilst Fallout 3 certainly introduced the mechanics we've come to expect in a modern day Fallout game, New Vegas innovates on them, adding flavour and variety to the otherwise cut and paste formula.  The allocation of skills and the dedication to your build feels more consequential here, and investing points into specific areas offers unique rewards depending on how you spec. This is something the newest entry, Fallout 4, failed to recreate, amongst other things.  Dialogue and interaction is fun, engaging and almost always unique. No two, important characters feel the same, and although the entire cast is voice acted by a very select group of actors (as is customary of a Bethesda game), most are memorable and impressionable on your playthrough. This, I feel, is one of the most important components of a Fallout game; How immersed do I feel? New Vegas strikes this balance between quirkiness and weighty decision-making perfectly, and what you end up with is a living, breathing world.  Story-wise, there is a surprising amount of depth and choice involved in the events of the world and your character. You are a courier, a nobody, and unlike other entries in the series, you start fresh, out in the wasteland without a vault in sight. You are given the option to be who you want to be, which is something I can really appreciate after playing through Fallout 4. Factions are introduced as a core mechanic in New Vegas and they essentially determine your characters path trhough the story and their allignment, but it goes beyond good and evil. There are a lot of morally grey decisions to be made, sacrifices to deal with and inevitably, you're going to have regrets about the things you do. It's a joy over and over and over...  I'm going to have to say this, gameplay is certainly New Vegas's weak point. In many instances, you'll either be talking your way out of something, or shooting. Whilst there is something to be said for the sheer volume of weaponry and the methodic VATS assisted dismemberment of your foes, it gets stale pretty quick, especially in the later levels. You'll probably find that abusing the enemy AI is the best way to fight and that hitting more, hitting often is always the best stategy. The difference between a plasma rifle and a semi-auto assault rifle is in the sound it makes, the puddle of goo it leaves and the blood it spills, but realistically, dispatching your enemies is consistent throughout.  Graphically, New Vegas hasn't exactly aged well. Fortunately, it's visual style and complex, memorable world design is engaging enough that you'll either fail to notice, or you'll care very little. The controls are agreeable and highly customisable, and a hotbar feature exists to quickly switch between your weapons and items.  Oh, and unlike Fallout 3, this game is a lot more functional on modern hardware.  I'd recommend solely based on replayability alone, but this game offers a lot more and is well worth the price.

As you can see, I've put a LOT of hours into Fallout NV. So why am I giving it a thumbs down? After playing FO4 I can see how bad FO:NV really is. To simply put it, good rpg but bad game. Like many people that've played NV, I've had my share of bugs. Lots of them still in the game in fact which is odd for a title this old. The world, even though it's beautiful in its unique way, turns quickly ugly and boring. There is a LOT of brown in this game, more than an actual desert. The only places with some color are Jamestown, New Vegas and the Vault with the plants. Other then those places, it's so...ugly.   As much as I love the NCR, Legion and all the other characters in the game the world still feels dead and barron. Many areas of the map don't have any creatures in it, creating awkard silent moments where you can truely see how alone you are in the game. There is random encounters but they are few and far in between. Really, everything is tucked into small pockets of the world. Cities and some important spots with items are really the only places with creatures.   As an RPG, the game is damn good. You can be what you want, when you want. Skills tie in to the speech system. If you are a doctor and are good a medicine, then you can help some people with that skill when talking to them. Its nice and it helps with the immersion of self-character.   Besides that, the game is horrible to play. Combat is just a bore and is more like a chore than anything else. It feels stiff and honestly, like goldeneye from N64. Also, you can become stupid strong real fast in the game just by having your specials maxed out for Intel and Luck. You'll have all skills to 100 before level 25 and be doing crit damage all over the place.   All in all, Fallout: NV just feels rushed and 'watered down' compared to other games. As a rpg, its great to a point but as a game, it's horrid to play repeatedly. It quickly becomes dull, even with mods (and I've modded mine to hell and back). If you love RPGs then yeah, pick it up. the game is dirt cheap now but prepare for freezes and crashes and a broken skill system.

I wanted to like this game (with its supposed focus on freedom and interesting characters), but could not. It felt very dated, and there were too many immersion breaking flaws and bugs. In terms of graphics, level design, and animations, this feels like a game from 2005 (to a lesser extent also true for TES:Oblivion, but it certainly bothered me less there). The main quest offers good freedom of choice, but otherwise quests are mostly quantity over quality – a hallmark of Bethesda. Some of the characters were entertaining though, and voice acting is fairly good. Character leveling and perks are also quite well done. The interface looks cool but is a total pain to use. There are no keyboard hotkeys, which means switching weapons or healing requires browsing through the full menu each time! Combat feels unbalanced (Oblivion and Skyrim were slightly better here) ranging from ok to frustratingly tedious or difficult. The difficulty of various foes often does not match with the expectations the game lore may give you. Enemies run around without any movement inertia making them frustratingly difficult to aim at. Hitbox detection is not great, and your bullets are often blocked by invisible walls if they pass near geometry. I also had lots of enemies get stuck behind geometry, with only legs clipping through the wall. Worst of all, at one point, my gun would not fire bullets – I would hear and see the gun fire, and the ammo counter would work, but no bullets – I got eaten alive, both ingame and in terms of frustration. The mod experience was bad: I could not get most mods to work despite following all instructions etc. The mod scene may be vibrant, but it is still a total mess. It lacks curatorial refinement and there are no “1-click install” total-overhaul supermods (like the “complete” mod series for the Stalker games).  Buried underneath all the flaws is a good game, and you might find it, but I gave up after days of digging.
